urn:contentItem:5T59-1KC1-DY0W-40V1-00000-00John McCain Is Honored In Arizona With Tears and Tributes; Florida Governor's Race Turns Ugly In Aftermath Of Primary; President Trump Accuses Google Of Biased Searches; Yahoo! And AOL Reportedly Scanning E-mail For Data To Sell; President Trump Slams Use Of Anonymous Sources By Reporters2018-08-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:18ZLexisNexisJohn McCain Is Honored In Arizona With Tears and Tributes; Florida Governor's Race Turns Ugly In Aftermath Of Primary; President Trump Accuses Google Of Biased Searches; Yahoo! And AOL Reportedly Scanning E-mail For Data To Sell; President Trump Slams Use Of Anonymous Sources By ReportersLanhamFULL TEXT

GUY BENSON, FOX NEWS HOST: Well, it's already being billed as an ideological showdown for the ages. Trumpism versus socialism and it's playing out before our very eyes in Florida's gubernatorial contest. Who will come out on top? I'm guy Benson in for Kennedy tonight. Last night, Republican Congressman Ron DeSantis won his primary and will now go up against the surprise Democratic winner, Tallahassee mayor Andrew Gillum.

But the race is way bigger than just Florida. It's actually in some ways a microcosm of the larger political battle raging across the nation. Here's why. DeSantis is a big supporter of President Trump and vice versa. Gillum is backed by Vermont socialist Senator Bernie Sanders, and the winner of this race might foreshadow what's to come in 2020. Last night, DeSantis claimed his opponent's policies will destroy Florida's economy. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. RON DESANTIS (R), FLORIDA: He is the most liberal candidate that the Democratic Party has ever nominated in the State of Florida by a country mile in a governor's race. He wants to abolish ICE, he wants a billion dollar tax increase, he wants a single-payer healthcare system in Florida which would bankrupt the state. I'm trying to make Florida even better. He wants to make FloridaVenezuela.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BENSON: Make Florida Venezuela again, that could go on a baseball cap. But Gillum claims that raising corporate taxes could actually attract new businesses. Hmm.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANDREW GILLUM, MAYOR OF TALLAHASSEE: What we have proposed is an increase in the corporate tax rate which in the State of Florida is lower than our neighboring States of Alabama and Georgia. Right now we're at 5-1/4 and we've suggested going up to just over seven which puts us in line with many other states and part of what -- it creates a billion dollars in funding for our public education system.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BENSON: OK. So what are the takeaways from last night and what does it mean going forward? Joining me now, former special assistant to President Trump and former press secretary to Vice President Mike Pence, Mark Lotter is here. And also here with me in New York, co-host of "THE FIVE," Juan Williams. Gentlemen, welcome.

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS POLITICAL ANALYST: Good evening.

MARK LOTTER, FORMER PRESS SECRETARY TO VICE PRESIDENT MIKE PENCE: Good to be here.

BENSON: Mark, I'll start with you. Another major endorsement victory for President Trump, dare we call this a winning streak?

LOTTER: I think so, and it's pretty clear when you see that Ron DeSantis was down by big double digits and after that endorsement he won by over -- by close to 20 points. So, big win for Ron DeSantis and I would say it's a big win for Florida because they've had a really good thing going in the last 20 years under Republican leadership. Not sure they're ready to turn their backs on that and embrace socialism.

BENSON: Juan, I'm actually fascinated by the dynamics of this race. We talked about a little bit of the top. It's almost a laboratory pure test of MAGA versus feel the burn here in the swingiest state in the country. How do you feel like this is going to shape up with these two candidates that frankly the other party will argue is unelectable?

WILLIAMS: Well, in fact, one of the arguments today I was hearing from political people is either side got the candidate they want to run against.

BENSON: Right.

WILLIAMS: And so here you have a situation where the question is the label socialist. So the Republican, the Trumpian, DeSantis, says my opponent is a socialist. And, in fact, we recently had a poll that you may have seen where most Democrats said they're fine with socialism.

BENSON: I mean, he won the primary.

WILLIAMS: Correct. But the question is this, is he a socialist? I don't think he accepts that label. He's not, certainly, about having the government takeover the means of production. We live in an age where there are lots of people -- we had a poll this week that found, I think, it's 40 percent of Americans said they had a hard time meeting bills for food, for housing and healthcare.

In an era of high-income inequality, is it socialist to say I believe in a social safety net that protects people from falling to the bottom?

BENSON: All right. Well, Mark, let's get your response to that because we can debate whether or not he's a socialist or a Democratic socialist, but as you heard from Ron DeSantis in that clip we just played, his opponent does support socialist healthcare. He wants to socialize healthcare in the state, abolish ICE. It's a pretty far-left agenda especially in a state like Florida which is kind of down the middle.

LOTTER: And you're absolutely right. And let's remember that he won that primary last night with only one-third of a very large Democratic vote. So two out of three Democratic voters said no. How is he going to convince them that his far-left policies, which are farther left than more even moderate, middle Democrats in Florida, that's a pretty extreme program he's embracing. We've got a lot of support, a lot of enthusiasm on the Republican side.

I think he's going to have a lot of work to do, especially in that I-4 corridor, trying to make moderate people embrace his very liberal, very progressive ideas.

BENSON: All right. So Juan, how does he do that? If you were recommending things to Andrew Gillum as he looks toward November at this point, he's won the primary, he checked the box. Bernie Sanders really helped him obviously. Does he campaign with Bernie? Does he remain a Bernie Democrat or does he start to sort of inch toward the center? And how can he do that?

WILLIAMS: Well, no, I think the key in all races right now, and I think you're going to see this across the country specifically in Georgia which also has a Democrat black woman running, Stacey Abrams running against a Trumpian, Brian Kemp, I think what you're going to see is they're saying we're going to talk about the issues from the Democratic perspective.

And the issue will be -- and this is what Gillum did in his race against other Democrats, say I'm the only non-millionaire in the race. I'm the one that really can identify --

BENSON: That's not an issue. That's not an issue.

WILLIAMS: Oh, it is. Because you want to say in a time of income inequality I relate to you, struggling people, who are out there working hard and having a hard time paying for your kids to go to college, college tuition. I'm the ones who can relate when a big medical bill comes in how threatened you are and how it throws off your budget. And I think that's what he's going to do.

It's not going to, you know, so I think Republicans may say, oh, sounds like socialism, but you know what? I wonder if voters instead will respond this is someone who shares my needs and understands my predicament.

LOTTER: But I'll tell you one thing in that response to Juan is all of those people who have jobs, who are looking for jobs, they're going to have small businesses, big business owners saying, well, because Gillum supports a $15.00 minimum wage, because he's raising taxes on our companies 40 percent, we are not going to be able to give you a race. We're not going to be able to hire you.

Well, we're going to fire you and replace you with a computer because it's costing us too much. That is a very powerful driver and you can bet the Chambers of Commerce and business groups are all going to be out there rallying people to stop the tax increase.

WILLIAMS: Well, Mark, you've got to hear from the teachers, you've got to hear from people who feel as if they're underpaid in terms of government. You've got to hear from the minority groups, larger and larger especially along that I-94 corridor that you mentioned, referenced earlier. These are people who are quite excited by Gillum. The question is, because I think the Republican base is excited by Trump and DeSantis.

The question is once you get beyond these two polarized bases, what does the middle think? What does the suburban house way?

BENSON: Yes. That's going to be, I think, one of the most fascinating races in the country. We'll watch it very closely. Mark, Juan, thank you both.

LOTTER: You're welcome.

WILLIAMS: Thanks.

BENSON: One thing is for sure under the economy that has been engineered by DeSantis' coach, President Trump, things are booming. Just today the government reported the U.S. economy grew 4.2 percent in the last quarter which is higher than previously estimate and the best quarter since 2014. A stronger economy has Americans more comfortable with their jobs as well.

A new report today claiming just over half of Americans, 51 percent say they're satisfied with their jobs, the highest level since 2005. Plus, consumer confidence also at an 18-year high. So while a lot of people love to hate this President, are his policies at least being vindicated? Fox News Contributor and chief investment officer of Kingsview Asset Management, Scott Martin is here with me now.

Scott, thanks for swinging by from Chicago, my former hometown. Go, Cubs.

SCOTT MARTIN, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: Yes. I mean, no problem. And sorry about all the heat we sent you, but I'm not telling you, I'm not missing it, man. So enjoy.

BENSON: Chicago -- people talk about Chicago winners but Chicago summers can be absolutely brutal. So Scott, I want to talk about these economic numbers today. The job security and job satisfaction statistics, I thought were interesting. We don't always hear about that metric. Why is it important?

MARTIN: Well, it says a lot of things. It says that employers are treating or their employees right for maybe the first time in several years via benefits, obviously 401(k) benefits are doing very well, we've seen those balances, Guy, at record highs. And job quality too. You know, I think with technology and things that are going on in the work force, Guy, I think people are happier in their jobs because they're doing more stuff in technology.

Maybe it's making their jobs easier. And then on the flipside too, you know, the employers are happy about that because companies are making more money, we have record profits, and you're seeing that show up in the data points.

BENSON: So I want to talk about a dichotomy here that is a little bit puzzling to me, because I can rattle off all the incredible numbers about the economy, unemployment, GDP growth, consumer confidence, the list goes on. We actually talked about a few of them just a moment ago and yet in our most recent Fox News poll, only 47 percent of Americans rank the U.S. economy right now as excellent or good.

With the other half saying only fair or poor. So objectively, the economy is in great shape, but the American people are polarized about whether it's really all that great. Why?

MARTIN: Yes. It's kind of weird, you know? It could be the media that they're ingesting, certainly, that's telling them those things. Or you could have just made it to, you know, the right haters on the street as far as that poll goes because to me, I've got to tell you, I mean, looking at those data points you mentioned, Guy, with the economy now growing at 4.2 percent, the best in several years.

Consumer confidence at highs that we haven't seen since I was prom king, business confidence as well --

BENSON: Were you really?

MARTIN: Very high. No. You know, when I came in second, and it was totally fixed --

(CROSSTALK)

BENSON: So that was fake news. I just called you out in fake news.

MARTIN: It was totally -- it was totally fixed man. The guy paid people off to vote for him. But either way, I should have been. And then secondly, listen like look at -- look at business confidence numbers. Now what we're seeing, Guy, that we haven't seen for many, many years because businesses weren't confident enough in the future, they're actually doing capital expenditures, research and development, investing in their employees.

Things that companies weren't doing a couple years ago because they were worried about the future, they were worried about regulations and taxes. All of that spending is now getting unlocked. So, I think those people you interviewed eventually are going to turn tail because they're just going to have to realize that the economy is better than they think.

BENSON: What do you make of this debate over whether we're on a sugar high right now and everything is great for the moment but it's going to go away, or is this unsustainable, is it sustainable to sort of this back and forth among economists and politicians. Where do you come down on that?

MARTIN: Yes. You know, I'm close to the sugar high camp. Not yet, but I will tell you that, you know, the way the markets are and the way that they've just been going up and up and up on almost seemingly bad news these days and, yes, we've had some good trade reconciliation news which does support the S&P 500, it will push up stock prices. But the reality is this, things are getting very good.

So if you just look back in history and look back at cycles, you know, things in the markets and economy occur, and cycles just like seasons of the year do, as you mentioned how hot it is in Chicago, it gets cold in Chicago as well just like it will on the East Coast. So, just remember that if you're investing for today, there is going to be a rainy day in the stock market, so as greatest things could be today, you've just got to have some things in your portfolio that will do well if the markets go down.

BENSON: Cyclical, I buy that, but how long is the cycle? That's such a huge question. When might we start to look for some potential downturn signs?

MARTIN: Yes. I'll tell you, man. I mean, things are going to change if the midterms go the wrong way. Let's say depending on who you're voting for, obviously that's a subjective comment.

BENSON: Right.

MARTIN: But if things go a bad way in November, that could be the start of it, Guy. And in 2020, let's face it, man, it's not that far away, so that's another twist that could be happening in the pipe here.

BENSON: Don't remind me. All right. Scott, thank you so much tonight. And stay cool in Chicago for now.

MARTIN: See you.

BENSON: On a more somber note tonight, thousands of mourners paying their respects today in honoring the life of war hero and longtime Senator John McCain who served his country for more than 60 years. Take a look there. A live look inside the Arizona State Capitol where the body of John McCain is lying in state.

Earlier today a police escort accompanied McCain's body to the Capitol as scores of military veterans, law enforcement, fire and first responders lined the sides of Capitol Plaza for the procession is. Fox News correspondent William La Jeunesse is with us Phoenix with more. William?

WILLIAM LA JEUNESSE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Well, Guy, it's about 106 degrees here, and it has been all day. And here is the amazing thing, the line that you see here, it snakes another quarter mile around the corner here. It's been that way uninterrupted for about four hours all for the chance to spend 20 or 30 seconds next to the casket of John McCain, just enough to say goodbye.

But, you know, many don't know John McCain planned these services. He personally reached out to the pallbearers and the ushers and the people who speak tomorrow to celebrate his life on what would have been his 82nd birthday. Now, there -- today was as you said, more solemn than celebration. Cindy and her two sons met the casket along with Governor Doug Ducey and his wife.

The casket will lie here until tomorrow morning in a motorcade to North Phoenix Baptist Church. Senator Jon Kyl who served with McCain said there was a debate on the floor of Congress he jointed, if there wasn't, McCain would start one. The country he said will miss his fight and his voice.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JON KYL, FORMER UNITED STATES SENATOR: John's love for America and Arizona. He represented our values all over the world as Senator from Arizona. And America is stronger for his fierce defense of our values. We can be proud he was our Senator.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LA JEUNESSE: Now, it was an emotional service with Cindy laying her head on the coffin, daughter Meghan openly crying, follow by McCain's sons, Governor Ducey recalled McCain's years in Vietnam fighting for his country down for the state he represented for 36 years.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KYL: When John McCain called upon us to serve a purpose greater than one's own self-interest, it wasn't a talking point designed to win the next election. It was how he had actually lived his life and continued to live his life. That's how he wanted us to live ours.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LA JEUNESSE: Even though McCain is gone, he is still sending a message of inclusivity and bipartisanship. Those speaking tomorrow include Democrats Joe Biden, the ushers and pallbearers are a mixed of -- well, a Hispanic woman, a native American, cardinal Larry Fitzgerald, ex-Diamondback Luis Gonzalez and in Washington many will come from across the aisle, Guy. As I said today, 106 degrees. That building was built in 1901.

It's very thick wall, it's going to remain kind of cool. But the people I spoke to said they came for several reasons. Obviously, his sacrifice in Vietnam. Some native Americans coming from five, six hours away on the Naval Reservation because of what he did for the tribes and Indian gaming, allowing that, pushing that legislation through. And then of course many just said, listen, he was there for us, it is our turn to be there for him and their chance to say goodbye. Back to you.

BENSON: William, thank you for that report. Moving day in Arizona. Coming up, back in D.C. President Trump attacking Hillary Clinton after a new report suggest China was able to hack into her e-mail server. Remember that one? But did it actually happen? Plus, another White House departure, White House Counsel Don McGahn leaving his post this fall. What does that mean for the President's legal team? Jason Chaffetz joins me after the break.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BENSON: President Trump calling for a new investigation into Hillary Clinton's private e-mail server. Earlier today the President tweeting, "Hillary Clinton's e-mails, many of which are classified information, got hacked by China. Next move better be by the FBI and DOJ or after all of their other missteps, Comey, McCabe, Strzok, Page or FISA dirty dossier et cetera, their credibility will be gone forever.

The President seemed to be referencing a Daily Caller report that cited anonymous sources in the intelligence community. The FBI later countering that, "the FBI has not found any evidence that the servers were compromised." The Chinese Foreign Ministry for their part also denying the report, LOL, of course they would, but is the President right to call out the intelligence community as potentially compromised?

Joining me now, former Utah Congressman and Fox News Contributor Jason Chaffetz. Jason, it's great to see you. You also have a forthcoming book, The Deep State, we're happy to have you here.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, thank you, I appreciate it. I look forward to the book coming out, and thanks for having me on.

BENSON: All right. So let's start with this Daily Caller report, what we saw form the President and his tweets and the FBI denying it, right? Denying this whole suggestion or report that China hacked into Hillary Clinton's bootleg basement e-mail server. I'm reminded, everyone from Robert Gates to Jim Comey to Mike Morrell said the chances were high that a hostile foreign power did get into that unsecure server.

You paid very close attention to this while you were in Congress, what do you think the truth is here?

CHAFFETZ: Oh, I think it's highly probable and most likely that it did happen. We heard testimony from the inspect general, Michael Horowitz, that they did believe that there was an intrusion on this computer. When I was the chairman of the oversight committee, we heard testimony from the person who set up the server, did not have a degree in computer science, had never taken a computer course.

It literally kind of, you know, went down to Best Buy and then set it up in the basement there. I mean, literally, that's how sloppily this was done. We never did get testimony from the secret service, you would think they would take some ownership given that within former President Clinton's home, but nevertheless it's -- I can't imagine that, A, she wasn't targeted. Of course she was. She was Secretary of State.

And then even as former Secretary of State, she was presidential candidate most likely at that point. And it's almost impossible to think that even some guy down by the river in a van could have done this probably. It's not a local 17-year-old, your local high schooler.

BENSON: Meantime, Jason, yesterday on Capitol Hill we saw Bruce Ohr arriving for closed-door testimony before some committees. You were, as you just referenced, the chairman of the Oversight Committee in the house. If you had been in that private session, what would have been some of the questions you were eager to ask Bruce Ohr?

CHAFFETZ: Well, what you want to do is play off what the FBI was telling you officially, because they have been fishy, at best, in provide documents, they have been hiding the ball for a long time and it ends up that more and more what Congressional investigators are finding out is what they weren't told even under oath is turning out not to be true. Particularly as it relates to this dossier, the funding of it.

The only evidence that we see of true collusion when money is changing hands is between Russians, the Democratic National Committee, a guy named Mark Elias. That name is out in the media, but it's going to be the center of the universe for so many of these things. And Bruce Ohr talking about how his wife Nelly is involved and engaged in this. I mean, it's a nefarious, salacious situation and yet no attention, but little to no attention by the FBI itself.

BENSON: All right, Jason. One more question here. The report today confirmed by the President, Don McGahn on his way out as White House Counsel. What's the effect at the White House? What do you make of that?

CHAFFETZ: Well, I don't know who filled those big shoes. I think Don McGahn has been a trusted adviser, close to the President, a superb job in the judicial nominees and selections certainly with the Supreme Court but also at the district court level and whatnot. There's no heir apparent that I'm aware of. And, you know, general counsel to the President of the United States is a very big role to fill. Especially in this White House.

BENSON: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: And so, he will be deeply missed. I don't know who steps up and fills that but it is of critical importance.

BENSON: Jason Chaffetz, thank you for your time. And good luck with the book.

CHAFFETZ: Thanks, Guy.

BENSON: Sure thing. Coming up. Should the government be able to regulate search engine results from Google? We'll tell you why President Trump seems to think so. Plus, a senior Facebook engineer speaking out claiming the company is biased against conservatives. The panel joins me next to discuss.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BENSON: Some new controversies today the involving major internet company that many of us use every single day, Facebook, Google, Yahoo! and Amazon. Let's start with Google and Facebook. Each of which are now mired in separate claims of bias against conservatives. Yesterday President Trump tweeted, "Google search results for Trump news shows only the viewing reporting of fake news media.

In order, they have rigged it for me and others so that almost all stories and news is bad. Fake CNN is prominent, Republican conservative and fair media is shut out. Illegal? 96 percent of results on Trump news are from national left-wing media, very dangerous. Google and others are suppressing voices of conservatives and is hiding information and news that is good. They are controlling what we can and cannot see.

This is a very serious situation. Will be addressed." Google responded saying there's no bias in search results. Over at Facebook, meanwhile, dozens of employees have reportedly united to challenge what they say is a left-swing culture at the social media giant. They're claiming conservative staffers shunned, marginalized and even harassed. So is the bias real, and what can or should be done about any of it if anything?

Let's go to the panel tonight. FBN's Deirdre Bolton is here, Jimmy Failla and Democratic strategist and attorney, Danielle McLaughlin. Hello, everyone.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey.

(CROSSTALK)

BENSON: Thanks for being here. All right. So, Deirdre, let's start with Google and the President maybe suggesting that some regulation might be coming down the pike. As we think about regulation from the federal government, looking at Google, private company but arguably sort of a public utility because they're a gateway to internet searches. How do you strike that balance?

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Well, we've heard the president criticized Google, right, as he has. We've also heard him say it's one of our greatest companies, and we know that there is this Senate Intelligence Committee hearing on September 5th. So, we have to assume that some of this is a little bit of grandstanding. And as you say, I mean, this is a publicly-traded company from a legal perspective, which I'm sure Danielle will help us out on.

I actually don't know what the government really can do even if they decided in some weird way to try to somehow restrict. I don't know, you would have freedom of speech infractions. I mean, you have a lot of problems if the government tries to outright regulate Google. And by the way, the president has also complained, right, about Facebook, and perhaps right so, also complained about Twitter --

BENSON: Lots of complaining.

BOLTON: So, I just think -- as we know, he tends to be very pure in whatever sentiments he is feeling at that particular moment.

BENSON: All right. So, Danielle, let's just say hypothetically, Google's denying any of this for the moment. But hypothetically, if Google was tweaking its formulas to promote an agenda or suppress some search results, would that be a problem?

DANIELLE MCLAUGHLIN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Constitutionally, no. I mean, the freedom of speech that we have, and corporations have freedom of speech as well, which we can decide whether that's a good thing or not, they have a lot of rights, protects us, protects corporations against government. So, it gives the freedom -- you know, what's the saying I hate what you say, but you know, I'll defend your right to say it. We see conservative media, we see liberal media, we used to have some cool neutrality which was required by the FCC. Not anymore. So, that's why we've seen the sort of - - we see now, we see Fox News, and we see MSNBC on the other side. There's not a lot that the president can do, and I think he calls it rigged when he doesn't like what he's seeing, frankly.

BENSON: Jimmy, are you willing to criticize Google in light of your own personal searches?

(LAUGHTER)

JIMMY FAILLA, COMEDIAN: I was just going to say that. I give him that credit.

BOLTON: Like prom jacket comes up sometimes.

MCLAUGHLIN: This is going to come up on Google tomorrow.

FAILLA: But you might search this, that so much to the president's point. I don't think anyone ever Googles the term "Trump news." You're never more than three-inches from Trump news in the world that we're living right now. But I think the reason he initiates this argument is not so much that he plans on regulating, but that he calls attention to it because it casts him in a sympathetic light. It's another attempt to remind everybody that the powers that be are aligned against him.

BENSON: Just briefly on the Facebook accusation for some of these employees, is it bad business for these big tech companies to overwhelmingly hire people from one political persuasion?

BOLTON: I actually was happy to hear of this one engineer who just said like, OK, it's 0.5 percent of employee base at Facebook, they have 25,000 employees -- something like a hundred signed up for this diversity committee. I personally would rather have a company. I think it is better for business to have tons of different points of view. And I think interestingly enough, even the people on Facebook who signed up for this diversity or political diversity opinion meeting even said we're not conservative, we're just sick of all the liberal slant and just feeling like we can't even hear a different point of view. So, yes, I think the best for business, open, open, open ideas, right? That's where you get the best creativity.

BENSON: All right. So, next topic, there was a time when advertisers hoped to read your mind, but nowadays they can just read your e-mails. The Wall Street Journal reporting that Yahoo! is scanning the e-mails from 200 million accounts to get information they can sell to advertisers. The report raises serious privacy questions but the tech company insists they never scan personal messages -- yes, sure -- and only target commercial products in an effort to deliver a more personalized advertising experience, which is a nice way to put it.

AOL also reportedly engaging in the same practice, but both companies quick to point out consumers can opt out of the targeted ads by logging on to a privacy dashboard that they launched in April. So, it's hard to imagine they're the only tech companies doing this, but they're definitely the only ones admitting it -- at least now that they've been caught by The Wall Street Journal. Is Yahoo! up to no good or just no good at keeping secrets? Jimmy, when I saw this story, I just assumed this was already happening because of my targeted ads. I see this all the time, like isn't everyone doing this?

FAILLA: Yes, we have this discussion earlier. I mean, the biggest shock to me was that people were still using Yahoo! and AOL. I was more shocked to hear that. And to the point of who's still using it, because in a lot of ways it's like the MySpace of e-mail. The only people still on it are, like, creeps, you know what I mean? So, it's all going to be ads for how to bury a body.

BENSON: I would point out, I'm not on this, but the woman who normally sits here, from what I'm told, might be on one of those two platforms, so watch it. You work for her. You work for her.

FAILLA: I just outed her.

BENSON: Danielle, any points here for candor on behalf of Yahoo!, or they're really just caught by newspaper and then they said, OK, fine.

MCLAUGHLIN: No. No points for -- you would think that (INAUDIBLE) after the Facebook/Cambridge Analytica ought to debacle that maybe opting in to something like this was a better idea for not only P.R. but just for the -- for consumer.

BOLTON: But they're defending it, actually, fairly funny, right? They're like, oh, it costs a lot of money to like keep these servers up and running, and you would have to pay if we didn't sell ads. I mean, in their defense, I do not work for Yahoo! Obviously, do not give a hoot, but they do say that they're not actually reading through your e-mail line by line. What they're saying is if you -- of course not -- if you open a trader account at T.D. Ameritrade, then when you log on, you will just see you're known as an investor then.

BENSON: Here's the other thing, and this is just a devil's advocate point. I'm generally on the privacy side of this, but like, in some ways, even though they're creepy, targeted ads are sort of useful somehow. Well, actually, yes, I do want that.

FAILLA: You'd rather see an ad for that, but wouldn't it be great if this is how we found Hillary's e-mails after all this time, it's a bunch of ads for bleach bit and stuff like that?

(LAUGHTER)

BENSON: All right. Amazon finally having enough of Bernie Sanders attacks. In a rare move, they made a public response to the socialist senator. Sanders has spent months slamming both Amazon's working conditions and pay, but the tech giant accused the Vermont senator of spreading "misleading statements and urged Sanders to visit one of the company's fulfillment centers."

Sanders shot back earlier today: "Many Amazon employees who work for the wealthiest person on earth are paid wages so low they can't make ends meet." He also threatened to call the Occupational Safety and Health Administration to investigate "unsafe working conditions in the company's warehouses." Keep in mind, President Trump has also been a vocal critic of Amazon, but for very different reasons, who's going to win this war of words?

Danielle, I'll start with you, I understand that Bernie Sanders has a problem with big successful businesses sometimes. People are voluntarily working for Amazon. Amazon today said, hey, not only you, senator, come on in, ask our employees. Ask them what they're experience have been. I think that's a pretty good response, don't you?

MCLAUGHLIN: I do. And I, of course, read Jeff Bezos' response, the average wage for a full-time worker at Amazon is over $15.00 an hour, which further than many states mandate. They get great medical benefits, they get maternity and paternity leave, they get stock. The issue that came up of this was people who have been part-time workers, people who had left Amazon and had worked very long. So, there are issues with corporate wealthy, don't get me work. If you're working full time, I don't think you should be needing to get food stamps, there's a problem there, but I don't think necessarily that Amazon is --

BENSON: Jimmy, part of me as a conservative, I want the send a bouquet of flowers to people like Bernie Sanders who are attacking these companies that Americans find super convenient. Like Amazon and Uber, like keep coming after things that make Americans' lives more affordable and more convenient. Keep doing it.

FAILLA: Yes, it's a dumb move. I mean, I think the reason he hates Amazon is because you can't make other people pay for your stuff on Amazon. It just kind of goes against his doctrine. But I think to the point of what they're paying people and how they're offering us an effective and efficient service, I think this is one of those errands where the effort to demonize everything you come across in this age we live in brings you into a lot of dark alleys. And you know, Bernie Sanders, like a lot of people who live in a $2 million home, is a man of the people who has several $2 million homes. He is the mand of people, but I think he's being a man of the wrong people on this one -- to Guy's --

BOLTON: Or a limousine liberal.

BENSON: Deirdre, if you're Amazon and Bezos, you're like I'm getting it from Bernie, I'm getting it from Trump, what is going on here?

BOLTON: Yes, but at least I have $155 billion --

BENSON: That's right, he can take the slings and arrows.

BOLTON: I think he can. Listen, he is a legendary business leader, he's the pioneer. Jeff Bezos, I'm sure, is used to being criticized. I am sure he can handle it. I thought the response was great. Although I do think it's notable -- usually he ignores, you know, 99 percent of the arrows that come his way. Apparently, he did feel like this one was worth responding to but that was the right response.

OK, ask our employees, come to a fulfillment center, see what it's like. And I think to your point, the criticism has been more on people who are not full-time employees. I've actually been to one of those fulfillment centers, and it's true, there's a lot of teachers or people who are trying to get other hours doing other things, and perhaps they're treated differently.

BENSON: On their own according, which is how a market works. All right. Panel, stick around. Coming up, President Trump amping up his war on the media, this time attacking the use of anonymous sources again. Journalists are swinging back, but does the president maybe have a point? The panel debates that next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BENSON: President Trump taking aim at one of his favorite targets today, blasting CNN after the network stood by a recent report about the infamous 2016 Trump Tower meeting even after it was at least partially discredited by their own source, Attorney Lanny Davis. The president tweeted: "Anonymous sources are really starting to burn the media. The fact that that many anonymous sources don't even exist, that's the fact," he said, "they are fiction made up by fake news reporters. Look at the lie that fake CNN is caught in now? They got caught red-handed, enemy of the people!" He also tweeted: "When you see anonymous source, stop reading the story, it is fiction."

Now, several members of the media are firing back noting that the president himself has acted as his own anonymous source in the past about himself and saying that officials in Trump's White House actually often prohibit reporters from naming them in stories. Back to help me separate fact from fiction, our panel, Deirdre, Jimmy, and Danielle. All right, so Danielle, it seems to me like sometimes the president's righteous indignation over things are sort of situational based on what he needs and how he's feeling in the moment. And I kind of have this sneaking suspicion that the next time there's a news report with anonymous sources saying good things about him or things that are helpful to him, maybe he'll share that story widely. Right? Am I wrong?

MCLAUGHLIN: I'm picking up what you're putting down. I think that's true. You know, this is a man who was known around New York City for decades as being his own anonymous source, launching stories that were good and were good for him related to his dating life and also some other stuff. These people often won't tell their stories unless they're given anonymity, and we've seen instances in history. You think about deep throat, we would never have known about Watergate in some aspects, if we hadn't had people who are willing to come forward but didn't want to be the identified.

BENSON: Jimmy, when you serve as your own anonymous source --

FAILLA: Which happens a lot.

BENSON: -- about you, do you change your accent? Like, how do you pull that off?

FAILLA: I do have a voice filter option, you know, on the iPhone, which I don't want to give away my trade secrets here. And these are brilliant move by Trump, because everybody sees through it, but he's strategically picking a fight with the media because a they're the one people that people hate more than him. You know, he has very low approval ratings, but people hate the media. This is like, if a band were to pick a fight with nickelback, you're always going to come off looking good in the exchange because no one's going to choose nickelback over you. And to his point, the media with all the critics he's levied on the media, he could never discredit them as much as they have discredited themselves. They've been terrible, and it should be said.

BENSON: In some cases, not all cases. A little bit more of a serious question. Deirdre, for you, about journalism, is going after the concept of anonymous sources and actually more of an undermining of journalism than yelling fake news or having a crowd boo at reporters if trying to tell the American people that all anonymous sources are fake, that to me seems like a more serious implication about journalism.

BOLTON: Yes. I actually hadn't thought of it that way, but I agree with you. And going back to what you were saying, I mean, there are tons of people who are willing to speak on backgrounds but certainly do not want to be quoted. And there would be a lot of mis-stories. No, I agree, that is a big part of our pipeline, right? At least it lets you know, like, in the best of the journalism senses, at least it lets you know what to chase.

BENSON: Right. Yes, I think the problem that you run into especially if you're CNN in this case, is when you protect one of your anonymous sources who then tells you -- actually tells America I was the anonymous source, and I'm changing my story, and you just stand by the original reporting.

FAILLA: Not the best look.

BENSON: Not the best. That's -- we're talking about it last night on this show, that's where Trump, I think, is just like ramping up and go straight after CNN, because they're creating their own problem. All right, panel, this was great, thank you so much. All right. We'll be right back. "TOPICAL STORM" is coming up next. It's a good one, my first shot at it. We'll see how it goes.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BENSON: A new study found that people who eat large quantities of meat and cheese will live longer than people who don't. Yes! The study was conducted by the University of Arby's -- they have the meats with special help from the Five Guys Institute. That is a complete delicious sham, and this is the "TOPICAL STORM."

Topic one. We begin tonight at the go Bananas Family Fun Center where you can't beat the prices, but you can beat fellow customers. According to their Web site, go Bananas is the finest family amusement center in the entire Chicago-land area. Kids just love their interactive games -- like pin the tail on the fistfight and duck, duck flying garbage can. This brawl reportedly breaking out after two parents got into a disagreement, at which point police were called because you can't just go around hitting people you disagree with, unless you're Antifa. In which case, some people at CNN might actually defend you. We are happy to report that nobody was injured or hurt during that arcade ambush, although four parents were arrested. The judge in the case have set their bail at 5,000 tickets.

Topic two. No fistfights at the Stanley Hotel in Estes Park, Colorado last night which is amazing because one guest was truly behaving like an animal. The Stanley Hotel became famous for inspiring Steven King's classic "The Shining." They don't normally get a lot of bears at the Stanley, what with the Wi-Fi and lack of gluten free menu options, which outrageous in 2018, good Lord. But this fella decided to stop by for some R&R because all work and no play makes Jack a dull boy -- and that's a shining reference, by the way, for those of you who might be under the age of 40, like me. Although I have seen the film when I was younger. I was absolutely terrified, despite telling my friends that I was definitely not terrified. Speaking of, "The Shining" was recently voted the greatest horror movie of all time, in a recent survey. Coming in second was the Clinton campaign. Got her again. Yes!

Topic three. A Massachusetts golfer has been telling friends for weeks that a fox is stealing his balls off the course. Yes, right, no one believed him until one day he learned how to record the Fox after reading Omarosa's book. This video is so crazy that when they showed it on the golf channel, it literally woke up nearly half of their audience. That is not a therapy animal, that is a ball-stealing fox. And the man feels vindicated because it turns out, the only person making up stories this week was Lanny Davis. His video is being called a sign of the times in the golf world because years ago golfers were worried about a tiger on the course. Nowadays, it's foxes. Tigers are too busy chasing Perkins' waitresses around to ruin your golf game. Also, unlike Democrats, that guy actually has a legit point when he blames his problems fox.

Topic four, a new hot dog stand opened up in Times Square yesterday, and the good news is, they were absolutely swarmed. The bad news? This is a nightmare. Absolute nightmare. They were swarmed by 30,000 bees who cut the line. Probably not going to improve their Yelp reviews. Police still aren't sure why the bees came to Times Square, they're actually still trying to figure out why any humans would go to Times Square. I mean, other than to get groped by someone in an Elmo costume. But besides that, I can't think of a good reason to show up to that general locale not too far from right here where I sit. The NYPD was forced to bring in a beekeeper to vacuum up the bees. And despite record-breaking temperatures, he wasn't taking any chances, so he put on a hazmat suit -- yes because of the bees, but mostly because of the ingredients in a New York City hot dog. The bees reportedly charged tourists $10.00 a pop for photos and enforced the price aggressively.

Topic five. Finally, tonight, a Montana man had his methamphetamine conviction overturned after, get this, the expert witness the state used against him was caught using -- drum roll -- methamphetamines during his testimony. I think I speak for everyone, by the way, that I'm shocked this story didn't take place in Florida. James Bochelle -- I mean, winner right there, like the rat tail -- allegedly caught with a glass pipe and several bags of meth back in 2017. Convicted two days later, but the analyst who handled the evidence recently admitted to taking the leftover meth home from the crime lab and even showing up to court high.

In fact, police say he was so high, he claimed Michael Avenatti could actually win the presidency. Although I'm not so sure that's crazy anymore, am I high? Kennedy is screaming at her television right now, yes! Because she's totally watching her own show on vacation. No. The analyst has been fired from his job, as expected, and Bochelle is going to get his own trial, a redo here, coming up later this fall -- just in time for pumpkin spice meth to come out which is extra delicious but a little higher in calories. That's the "TOPICAL STORM." We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BENSON: That's our show, you guys. Three down, one to go for me. The lady returns next week. You can catch me on radio, by the way, "BENSON AND HARF," Fox News Radio, weeknights 6-8 p.m. Eastern, Bensonandharf.com. Tomorrow right here, we have Shannon Bream, Chris Stirewalt, Rachel Campos- Duffy. Look at that line up. I'm Guy Benson, in for Kennedy, and tonight we'll leave you with a live look at Phoenix where Senator John McCain lies in state.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: A babe who photographed babies...

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: She would get them to do the craziest things.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: ...becomes a celebrity herself.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

END

urn:contentItem:5T50-FKP1-JB20-G3S0-00000-00John McCain Is Honored In Arizona With Tears and Tributes; Florida Governor's Race Turns Ugly In Aftermath Of Primary; President Trump Accuses Google Of Biased Searches; Yahoo! And AOL Reportedly Scanning E-mail For Data To Sell; President Trump Slams Use Of Anonymous Sources By Reporters2018-08-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:18ZLexisNexisKENNEDY8:00 PM ESTMark Lotter, Scott Martin, Danielle McLaughlin, Jimmy FaillaNEWSFinancial082901cb.234John McCain Is Honored In Arizona With Tears and Tributes; Florida Governor's Race Turns Ugly In Aftermath Of Primary; President Trump Accuses Google Of Biased Searches; Yahoo! And AOL Reportedly Scanning E-mail For Data To Sell; President Trump Slams Use Of Anonymous Sources By ReportersGuy Benson, Juan Williams, William La Jeunesse, Jason Chaffetz; Deirdre Bolton

GUY BENSON, FOX NEWS HOST: Well, it's already being billed as an ideological showdown for the ages. Trumpism versus socialism and it's playing out before our very eyes in Florida's gubernatorial contest. Who will come out on top? I'm guy Benson in for Kennedy tonight. Last night, Republican Congressman Ron DeSantis won his primary and will now go up against the surprise Democratic winner, Tallahassee mayor Andrew Gillum.

But the race is way bigger than just Florida. It's actually in some ways a microcosm of the larger political battle raging across the nation. Here's why. DeSantis is a big supporter of President Trump and vice versa. Gillum is backed by Vermont socialist Senator Bernie Sanders, and the winner of this race might foreshadow what's to come in 2020. Last night, DeSantis claimed his opponent's policies will destroy Florida's economy. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. RON DESANTIS (R), FLORIDA: He is the most liberal candidate that the Democratic Party has ever nominated in the State of Florida by a country mile in a governor's race. He wants to abolish ICE, he wants a billion dollar tax increase, he wants a single-payer healthcare system in Florida which would bankrupt the state. I'm trying to make Florida even better. He wants to make FloridaVenezuela.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BENSON: Make Florida Venezuela again, that could go on a baseball cap. But Gillum claims that raising corporate taxes could actually attract new businesses. Hmm.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANDREW GILLUM, MAYOR OF TALLAHASSEE: What we have proposed is an increase in the corporate tax rate which in the State of Florida is lower than our neighboring States of Alabama and Georgia. Right now we're at 5-1/4 and we've suggested going up to just over seven which puts us in line with many other states and part of what -- it creates a billion dollars in funding for our public education system.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BENSON: OK. So what are the takeaways from last night and what does it mean going forward? Joining me now, former special assistant to President Trump and former press secretary to Vice President Mike Pence, Mark Lotter is here. And also here with me in New York, co-host of "THE FIVE," Juan Williams. Gentlemen, welcome.

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS POLITICAL ANALYST: Good evening.

MARK LOTTER, FORMER PRESS SECRETARY TO VICE PRESIDENT MIKE PENCE: Good to be here.

BENSON: Mark, I'll start with you. Another major endorsement victory for President Trump, dare we call this a winning streak?

LOTTER: I think so, and it's pretty clear when you see that Ron DeSantis was down by big double digits and after that endorsement he won by over -- by close to 20 points. So, big win for Ron DeSantis and I would say it's a big win for Florida because they've had a really good thing going in the last 20 years under Republican leadership. Not sure they're ready to turn their backs on that and embrace socialism.

BENSON: Juan, I'm actually fascinated by the dynamics of this race. We talked about a little bit of the top. It's almost a laboratory pure test of MAGA versus feel the burn here in the swingiest state in the country. How do you feel like this is going to shape up with these two candidates that frankly the other party will argue is unelectable?

WILLIAMS: Well, in fact, one of the arguments today I was hearing from political people is either side got the candidate they want to run against.

BENSON: Right.

WILLIAMS: And so here you have a situation where the question is the label socialist. So the Republican, the Trumpian, DeSantis, says my opponent is a socialist. And, in fact, we recently had a poll that you may have seen where most Democrats said they're fine with socialism.

BENSON: I mean, he won the primary.

WILLIAMS: Correct. But the question is this, is he a socialist? I don't think he accepts that label. He's not, certainly, about having the government takeover the means of production. We live in an age where there are lots of people -- we had a poll this week that found, I think, it's 40 percent of Americans said they had a hard time meeting bills for food, for housing and healthcare.

In an era of high-income inequality, is it socialist to say I believe in a social safety net that protects people from falling to the bottom?

BENSON: All right. Well, Mark, let's get your response to that because we can debate whether or not he's a socialist or a Democratic socialist, but as you heard from Ron DeSantis in that clip we just played, his opponent does support socialist healthcare. He wants to socialize healthcare in the state, abolish ICE. It's a pretty far-left agenda especially in a state like Florida which is kind of down the middle.

LOTTER: And you're absolutely right. And let's remember that he won that primary last night with only one-third of a very large Democratic vote. So two out of three Democratic voters said no. How is he going to convince them that his far-left policies, which are farther left than more even moderate, middle Democrats in Florida, that's a pretty extreme program he's embracing. We've got a lot of support, a lot of enthusiasm on the Republican side.

I think he's going to have a lot of work to do, especially in that I-4 corridor, trying to make moderate people embrace his very liberal, very progressive ideas.

BENSON: All right. So Juan, how does he do that? If you were recommending things to Andrew Gillum as he looks toward November at this point, he's won the primary, he checked the box. Bernie Sanders really helped him obviously. Does he campaign with Bernie? Does he remain a Bernie Democrat or does he start to sort of inch toward the center? And how can he do that?

WILLIAMS: Well, no, I think the key in all races right now, and I think you're going to see this across the country specifically in Georgia which also has a Democrat black woman running, Stacey Abrams running against a Trumpian, Brian Kemp, I think what you're going to see is they're saying we're going to talk about the issues from the Democratic perspective.

And the issue will be -- and this is what Gillum did in his race against other Democrats, say I'm the only non-millionaire in the race. I'm the one that really can identify --

BENSON: That's not an issue. That's not an issue.

WILLIAMS: Oh, it is. Because you want to say in a time of income inequality I relate to you, struggling people, who are out there working hard and having a hard time paying for your kids to go to college, college tuition. I'm the ones who can relate when a big medical bill comes in how threatened you are and how it throws off your budget. And I think that's what he's going to do.

No, I agree, that is a big part of our pipeline, right? At least it lets you know, like, in the best of the journalism senses, at least it lets you know what to chase.

BENSON: Right. Yes, I think the problem that you run into especially if you're CNN in this case, is when you protect one of your anonymous sources who then tells you -- actually tells America I was the anonymous source, and I'm changing my story, and you just stand by the original reporting.

FAILLA: Not the best look.

BENSON: Not the best. That's -- we're talking about it last night on this show, that's where Trump, I think, is just like ramping up and go straight after CNN, because they're creating their own problem. All right, panel, this was great, thank you so much. All right. We'll be right back. "TOPICAL STORM" is coming up next. It's a good one, my first shot at it. We'll see how it goes.

BENSON: A new study found that people who eat large quantities of meat and cheese will live longer than people who don't. Yes! The study was conducted by the University of Arby's -- they have the meats with special help from the Five Guys Institute. That is a complete delicious sham, and this is the "TOPICAL STORM."

Topic one. We begin tonight at the go Bananas Family Fun Center where you can't beat the prices, but you can beat fellow customers. According to their Web site, go Bananas is the finest family amusement center in the entire Chicago-land area. Kids just love their interactive games -- like pin the tail on the fistfight and duck, duck flying garbage can. This brawl reportedly breaking out after two parents got into a disagreement, at which point police were called because you can't just go around hitting people you disagree with, unless you're Antifa. In which case, some people at CNN might actually defend you. We are happy to report that nobody was injured or hurt during that arcade ambush, although four parents were arrested. The judge in the case have set their bail at 5,000 tickets.

Topic two. No fistfights at the Stanley Hotel in Estes Park, Colorado last night which is amazing because one guest was truly behaving like an animal. The Stanley Hotel became famous for inspiring Steven King's classic "The Shining." They don't normally get a lot of bears at the Stanley, what with the Wi-Fi and lack of gluten free menu options, which outrageous in 2018, good Lord. But this fella decided to stop by for some R&R because all work and no play makes Jack a dull boy -- and that's a shining reference, by the way, for those of you who might be under the age of 40, like me. Although I have seen the film when I was younger. I was absolutely terrified, despite telling my friends that I was definitely not terrified. Speaking of, "The Shining" was recently voted the greatest horror movie of all time, in a recent survey. Coming in second was the Clinton campaign. Got her again. Yes!

Topic three. A Massachusetts golfer has been telling friends for weeks that a fox is stealing his balls off the course. Yes, right, no one believed him until one day he learned how to record the Fox after reading Omarosa's book. This video is so crazy that when they showed it on the golf channel, it literally woke up nearly half of their audience. That is not a therapy animal, that is a ball-stealing fox. And the man feels vindicated because it turns out, the only person making up stories this week was Lanny Davis. His video is being called a sign of the times in the golf world because years ago golfers were worried about a tiger on the course. Nowadays, it's foxes. Tigers are too busy chasing Perkins' waitresses around to ruin your golf game. Also, unlike Democrats, that guy actually has a legit point when he blames his problems fox.

Topic four, a new hot dog stand opened up in Times Square yesterday, and the good news is, they were absolutely swarmed. The bad news? This is a nightmare. Absolute nightmare. They were swarmed by 30,000 bees who cut the line. Probably not going to improve their Yelp reviews. Police still aren't sure why the bees came to Times Square, they're actually still trying to figure out why any humans would go to Times Square. I mean, other than to get groped by someone in an Elmo costume. But besides that, I can't think of a good reason to show up to that general locale not too far from right here where I sit. The NYPD was forced to bring in a beekeeper to vacuum up the bees. And despite record-breaking temperatures, he wasn't taking any chances, so he put on a hazmat suit -- yes because of the bees, but mostly because of the ingredients in a New York City hot dog. The bees reportedly charged tourists $10.00 a pop for photos and enforced the price aggressively.

Topic five. Finally, tonight, a Montana man had his methamphetamine conviction overturned after, get this, the expert witness the state used against him was caught using -- drum roll -- methamphetamines during his testimony. I think I speak for everyone, by the way, that I'm shocked this story didn't take place in Florida. James Bochelle -- I mean, winner right there, like the rat tail -- allegedly caught with a glass pipe and several bags of meth back in 2017. Convicted two days later, but the analyst who handled the evidence recently admitted to taking the leftover meth home from the crime lab and even showing up to court high.

In fact, police say he was so high, he claimed Michael Avenatti could actually win the presidency. Although I'm not so sure that's crazy anymore, am I high? Kennedy is screaming at her television right now, yes! Because she's totally watching her own show on vacation. No. The analyst has been fired from his job, as expected, and Bochelle is going to get his own trial, a redo here, coming up later this fall -- just in time for pumpkin spice meth to come out which is extra delicious but a little higher in calories. That's the "TOPICAL STORM." We'll be right back.

BENSON: That's our show, you guys. Three down, one to go for me. The lady returns next week. You can catch me on radio, by the way, "BENSON AND HARF," Fox News Radio, weeknights 6-8 p.m. Eastern, Bensonandharf.com. Tomorrow right here, we have Shannon Bream, Chris Stirewalt, Rachel Campos- Duffy. Look at that line up. I'm Guy Benson, in for Kennedy, and tonight we'll leave you with a live look at Phoenix where Senator John McCain lies in state.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: A babe who photographed babies...

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: She would get them to do the craziest things.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: ...becomes a celebrity herself.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T59-1KC1-DY0W-40W8-00000-00John McCain Is Honored In Arizona With Tears and Tributes; Florida Governor's Race Turns Ugly In Aftermath Of Primary; President Trump Accuses Google Of Biased Searches; Yahoo! And AOL Reportedly Scanning E-mail For Data To Sell; President Trump Slams Use Of Anonymous Sources By Reporters2018-08-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:18ZLexisNexisJohn McCain Is Honored In Arizona With Tears and Tributes; Florida Governor's Race Turns Ugly In Aftermath Of Primary; President Trump Accuses Google Of Biased Searches; Yahoo! And AOL Reportedly Scanning E-mail For Data To Sell; President Trump Slams Use Of Anonymous Sources By ReportersLanhamFULL TEXT

GUY BENSON, FOX NEWS HOST: Well, it's already being billed as an ideological showdown for the ages. Trumpism versus socialism and it's playing out before our very eyes in Florida's gubernatorial contest. Who will come out on top? I'm guy Benson in for Kennedy tonight. Last night, Republican Congressman Ron DeSantis won his primary and will now go up against the surprise Democratic winner, Tallahassee mayor Andrew Gillum.

But the race is way bigger than just Florida. It's actually in some ways a microcosm of the larger political battle raging across the nation. Here's why. DeSantis is a big supporter of President Trump and vice versa. Gillum is backed by Vermont socialist Senator Bernie Sanders, and the winner of this race might foreshadow what's to come in 2020. Last night, DeSantis claimed his opponent's policies will destroy Florida's economy. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. RON DESANTIS (R), FLORIDA: He is the most liberal candidate that the Democratic Party has ever nominated in the State of Florida by a country mile in a governor's race. He wants to abolish ICE, he wants a billion dollar tax increase, he wants a single-payer healthcare system in Florida which would bankrupt the state. I'm trying to make Florida even better. He wants to make FloridaVenezuela.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BENSON: Make Florida Venezuela again, that could go on a baseball cap. But Gillum claims that raising corporate taxes could actually attract new businesses. Hmm.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANDREW GILLUM, MAYOR OF TALLAHASSEE: What we have proposed is an increase in the corporate tax rate which in the State of Florida is lower than our neighboring States of Alabama and Georgia. Right now we're at 5-1/4 and we've suggested going up to just over seven which puts us in line with many other states and part of what -- it creates a billion dollars in funding for our public education system.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BENSON: OK. So what are the takeaways from last night and what does it mean going forward? Joining me now, former special assistant to President Trump and former press secretary to Vice President Mike Pence, Mark Lotter is here. And also here with me in New York, co-host of "THE FIVE," Juan Williams. Gentlemen, welcome.

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS POLITICAL ANALYST: Good evening.

MARK LOTTER, FORMER PRESS SECRETARY TO VICE PRESIDENT MIKE PENCE: Good to be here.

BENSON: Mark, I'll start with you. Another major endorsement victory for President Trump, dare we call this a winning streak?

LOTTER: I think so, and it's pretty clear when you see that Ron DeSantis was down by big double digits and after that endorsement he won by over -- by close to 20 points. So, big win for Ron DeSantis and I would say it's a big win for Florida because they've had a really good thing going in the last 20 years under Republican leadership. Not sure they're ready to turn their backs on that and embrace socialism.

BENSON: Juan, I'm actually fascinated by the dynamics of this race. We talked about a little bit of the top. It's almost a laboratory pure test of MAGA versus feel the burn here in the swingiest state in the country. How do you feel like this is going to shape up with these two candidates that frankly the other party will argue is unelectable?

WILLIAMS: Well, in fact, one of the arguments today I was hearing from political people is either side got the candidate they want to run against.

BENSON: Right.

WILLIAMS: And so here you have a situation where the question is the label socialist. So the Republican, the Trumpian, DeSantis, says my opponent is a socialist. And, in fact, we recently had a poll that you may have seen where most Democrats said they're fine with socialism.

BENSON: I mean, he won the primary.

WILLIAMS: Correct. But the question is this, is he a socialist? I don't think he accepts that label. He's not, certainly, about having the government takeover the means of production. We live in an age where there are lots of people -- we had a poll this week that found, I think, it's 40 percent of Americans said they had a hard time meeting bills for food, for housing and healthcare.

In an era of high-income inequality, is it socialist to say I believe in a social safety net that protects people from falling to the bottom?

BENSON: All right. Well, Mark, let's get your response to that because we can debate whether or not he's a socialist or a Democratic socialist, but as you heard from Ron DeSantis in that clip we just played, his opponent does support socialist healthcare. He wants to socialize healthcare in the state, abolish ICE. It's a pretty far-left agenda especially in a state like Florida which is kind of down the middle.

LOTTER: And you're absolutely right. And let's remember that he won that primary last night with only one-third of a very large Democratic vote. So two out of three Democratic voters said no. How is he going to convince them that his far-left policies, which are farther left than more even moderate, middle Democrats in Florida, that's a pretty extreme program he's embracing. We've got a lot of support, a lot of enthusiasm on the Republican side.

I think he's going to have a lot of work to do, especially in that I-4 corridor, trying to make moderate people embrace his very liberal, very progressive ideas.

BENSON: All right. So Juan, how does he do that? If you were recommending things to Andrew Gillum as he looks toward November at this point, he's won the primary, he checked the box. Bernie Sanders really helped him obviously. Does he campaign with Bernie? Does he remain a Bernie Democrat or does he start to sort of inch toward the center? And how can he do that?

WILLIAMS: Well, no, I think the key in all races right now, and I think you're going to see this across the country specifically in Georgia which also has a Democrat black woman running, Stacey Abrams running against a Trumpian, Brian Kemp, I think what you're going to see is they're saying we're going to talk about the issues from the Democratic perspective.

And the issue will be -- and this is what Gillum did in his race against other Democrats, say I'm the only non-millionaire in the race. I'm the one that really can identify --

BENSON: That's not an issue. That's not an issue.

WILLIAMS: Oh, it is. Because you want to say in a time of income inequality I relate to you, struggling people, who are out there working hard and having a hard time paying for your kids to go to college, college tuition. I'm the ones who can relate when a big medical bill comes in how threatened you are and how it throws off your budget. And I think that's what he's going to do.

It's not going to, you know, so I think Republicans may say, oh, sounds like socialism, but you know what? I wonder if voters instead will respond this is someone who shares my needs and understands my predicament.

LOTTER: But I'll tell you one thing in that response to Juan is all of those people who have jobs, who are looking for jobs, they're going to have small businesses, big business owners saying, well, because Gillum supports a $15.00 minimum wage, because he's raising taxes on our companies 40 percent, we are not going to be able to give you a race. We're not going to be able to hire you.

Well, we're going to fire you and replace you with a computer because it's costing us too much. That is a very powerful driver and you can bet the Chambers of Commerce and business groups are all going to be out there rallying people to stop the tax increase.

WILLIAMS: Well, Mark, you've got to hear from the teachers, you've got to hear from people who feel as if they're underpaid in terms of government. You've got to hear from the minority groups, larger and larger especially along that I-94 corridor that you mentioned, referenced earlier. These are people who are quite excited by Gillum. The question is, because I think the Republican base is excited by Trump and DeSantis.

The question is once you get beyond these two polarized bases, what does the middle think? What does the suburban house way?

BENSON: Yes. That's going to be, I think, one of the most fascinating races in the country. We'll watch it very closely. Mark, Juan, thank you both.

LOTTER: You're welcome.

WILLIAMS: Thanks.

BENSON: One thing is for sure under the economy that has been engineered by DeSantis' coach, President Trump, things are booming. Just today the government reported the U.S. economy grew 4.2 percent in the last quarter which is higher than previously estimate and the best quarter since 2014. A stronger economy has Americans more comfortable with their jobs as well.

A new report today claiming just over half of Americans, 51 percent say they're satisfied with their jobs, the highest level since 2005. Plus, consumer confidence also at an 18-year high. So while a lot of people love to hate this President, are his policies at least being vindicated? Fox News Contributor and chief investment officer of Kingsview Asset Management, Scott Martin is here with me now.

Scott, thanks for swinging by from Chicago, my former hometown. Go, Cubs.

SCOTT MARTIN, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: Yes. I mean, no problem. And sorry about all the heat we sent you, but I'm not telling you, I'm not missing it, man. So enjoy.

BENSON: Chicago -- people talk about Chicago winners but Chicago summers can be absolutely brutal. So Scott, I want to talk about these economic numbers today. The job security and job satisfaction statistics, I thought were interesting. We don't always hear about that metric. Why is it important?

MARTIN: Well, it says a lot of things. It says that employers are treating or their employees right for maybe the first time in several years via benefits, obviously 401(k) benefits are doing very well, we've seen those balances, Guy, at record highs. And job quality too. You know, I think with technology and things that are going on in the work force, Guy, I think people are happier in their jobs because they're doing more stuff in technology.

Maybe it's making their jobs easier. And then on the flipside too, you know, the employers are happy about that because companies are making more money, we have record profits, and you're seeing that show up in the data points.

BENSON: So I want to talk about a dichotomy here that is a little bit puzzling to me, because I can rattle off all the incredible numbers about the economy, unemployment, GDP growth, consumer confidence, the list goes on. We actually talked about a few of them just a moment ago and yet in our most recent Fox News poll, only 47 percent of Americans rank the U.S. economy right now as excellent or good.

With the other half saying only fair or poor. So objectively, the economy is in great shape, but the American people are polarized about whether it's really all that great. Why?

MARTIN: Yes. It's kind of weird, you know? It could be the media that they're ingesting, certainly, that's telling them those things. Or you could have just made it to, you know, the right haters on the street as far as that poll goes because to me, I've got to tell you, I mean, looking at those data points you mentioned, Guy, with the economy now growing at 4.2 percent, the best in several years.

Consumer confidence at highs that we haven't seen since I was prom king, business confidence as well --

BENSON: Were you really?

MARTIN: Very high. No. You know, when I came in second, and it was totally fixed --

(CROSSTALK)

BENSON: So that was fake news. I just called you out in fake news.

MARTIN: It was totally -- it was totally fixed man. The guy paid people off to vote for him. But either way, I should have been. And then secondly, listen like look at -- look at business confidence numbers. Now what we're seeing, Guy, that we haven't seen for many, many years because businesses weren't confident enough in the future, they're actually doing capital expenditures, research and development, investing in their employees.

Things that companies weren't doing a couple years ago because they were worried about the future, they were worried about regulations and taxes. All of that spending is now getting unlocked. So, I think those people you interviewed eventually are going to turn tail because they're just going to have to realize that the economy is better than they think.

BENSON: What do you make of this debate over whether we're on a sugar high right now and everything is great for the moment but it's going to go away, or is this unsustainable, is it sustainable to sort of this back and forth among economists and politicians. Where do you come down on that?

MARTIN: Yes. You know, I'm close to the sugar high camp. Not yet, but I will tell you that, you know, the way the markets are and the way that they've just been going up and up and up on almost seemingly bad news these days and, yes, we've had some good trade reconciliation news which does support the S&P 500, it will push up stock prices. But the reality is this, things are getting very good.

So if you just look back in history and look back at cycles, you know, things in the markets and economy occur, and cycles just like seasons of the year do, as you mentioned how hot it is in Chicago, it gets cold in Chicago as well just like it will on the East Coast. So, just remember that if you're investing for today, there is going to be a rainy day in the stock market, so as greatest things could be today, you've just got to have some things in your portfolio that will do well if the markets go down.

BENSON: Cyclical, I buy that, but how long is the cycle? That's such a huge question. When might we start to look for some potential downturn signs?

MARTIN: Yes. I'll tell you, man. I mean, things are going to change if the midterms go the wrong way. Let's say depending on who you're voting for, obviously that's a subjective comment.

BENSON: Right.

MARTIN: But if things go a bad way in November, that could be the start of it, Guy. And in 2020, let's face it, man, it's not that far away, so that's another twist that could be happening in the pipe here.

BENSON: Don't remind me. All right. Scott, thank you so much tonight. And stay cool in Chicago for now.

MARTIN: See you.

BENSON: On a more somber note tonight, thousands of mourners paying their respects today in honoring the life of war hero and longtime Senator John McCain who served his country for more than 60 years. Take a look there. A live look inside the Arizona State Capitol where the body of John McCain is lying in state.

Earlier today a police escort accompanied McCain's body to the Capitol as scores of military veterans, law enforcement, fire and first responders lined the sides of Capitol Plaza for the procession is. Fox News correspondent William La Jeunesse is with us Phoenix with more. William?

WILLIAM LA JEUNESSE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Well, Guy, it's about 106 degrees here, and it has been all day.
