Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5SXN-T1V1-DXH2-62XJ-00000-00John Streur is interviewed on BB Surveillance.2018-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:18ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG TV12:00 AM ESTJohn Streur, Francine LacquaNEWSInternational073089cb.550John Streur is interviewed on BB Surveillance.Tom Keene

John Streur discusses economics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

JOHN STREUR, PRESIDENT AND CEO, CALVERT INVESTMENTS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB SURVEILLACNE

JULY 30, 2018

SPEAKERS: JOHN STREUR, PRESIDENT AND CEO, CALVERT INVESTMENTS

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Well, that investor is John Streur. He is the President and Chief Executive of Calvert Investments, and he joins us now from Washington D.C. John Streur, thank you so much for joining us. Where will this all end up? If you look at privacy, when you look at regulation, really, being spearheaded by, I guess, the European Union, but then also reaching across the channel and across, of course, the U.S., where does it end for a lot of these big tech companies?

JOHN STREUR, PRESIDENT AND CEO, CALVERT INVESTMENTS: Well, I think it ends in more regulation and higher costs for these companies, and that creates a significant amount of near term uncertainty in terms of how advertisers are going to respond to these changes.

LACQUA: Okay. Who will be the winners and who will be the losers? So, I mean, you say that you felt vindicated after you sell on Facebook. But Facebook could actually change more into something else.

STREUR: Look, I think it's (inaudible), I think Facebook's business model is fairly dependent upon their advertizing revenue. If we take a look at Facebook and Twitter, those are their primary revenue sources. So if we look at a company like Google or Amazon or other major platforms, they're showing us that they have significantly other opportunities to generate revenue, particularly cloud computing, which really came through for Google in the most recent period. So Facebook is very, very dependent and its ability to expose a large number of users to all sorts of inputs, conduct this really large scale psychological experiment and sell that information to advertisers. That's what's really coming under pressure and Facebook doesn't have a lot of other options.

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: John, what you people invented with John Rogers on Chicago years ago in the Calvert Social Investment Fund, which at that time, folks, was absolutely revolutionary was, well, let's not buy tobacco, let's not buy this, let's not buy that. What has changed in social investment now? You were odd. Now, you're the norm. What is your day like in explaining the institutional money how to do social investment best?

STREUR: Well, that's -- thanks for the history. That's exactly right. I think what has really changed today is the amount of information that we have to work with to understand both what to buy as well as what you mentioned what not to buy. So today, our day is really all about understanding what is financially material in terms of environment performance, social impact, societal impact to companies.

KEENE: Put to rest the idea of rate of return. What is the tangible research you have, the tangible reality of rate of return or internal rate of return of social investment versus a blended SPX portfolio?

STREUR: Social investment can do anything non-social investment can do in terms of creating investment outcomes. There is really no reason to think about the return stream being different from social --

KEENE: Can you say the return stream is better? Can you say you're going to pick up 30 basis points with me?

STREUR: Well, I think you can say that. It depends on who is really applying the research though. So, as I said, we can do anything that you can do with non-social investing. We manufacture indexes at Calvert and they generally track the broad market. Sometimes we're slightly less risk, but that's the big measure. Can we create an inventory of securities that is capable to replicating the broad market returns. From there, sure, you can outperform especially if you add good active stock picking to that equation.

LACQUA: All right. John, thank you so much. John Streur there, President and Chief Executive Officer of Calvert Investment.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5SXT-SK31-DY0W-44TP-00000-00John Streur is interviewed on BB Surveillance.2018-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:17ZLexisNexisJohn Streur is interviewed on BB Surveillance.LanhamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

JOHN STREUR, PRESIDENT AND CEO, CALVERT INVESTMENTS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB SURVEILLACNE

JULY 30, 2018

SPEAKERS: JOHN STREUR, PRESIDENT AND CEO, CALVERT INVESTMENTS

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Well, that investor is John Streur. He is the President and Chief Executive of Calvert Investments, and he joins us now from Washington D.C. John Streur, thank you so much for joining us. Where will this all end up? If you look at privacy, when you look at regulation, really, being spearheaded by, I guess, the European Union, but then also reaching across the channel and across, of course, the U.S., where does it end for a lot of these big tech companies?

JOHN STREUR, PRESIDENT AND CEO, CALVERT INVESTMENTS: Well, I think it ends in more regulation and higher costs for these companies, and that creates a significant amount of near term uncertainty in terms of how advertisers are going to respond to these changes.

LACQUA: Okay. Who will be the winners and who will be the losers? So, I mean, you say that you felt vindicated after you sell on Facebook. But Facebook could actually change more into something else.

STREUR: Look, I think it's (inaudible), I think Facebook's business model is fairly dependent upon their advertizing revenue. If we take a look at Facebook and Twitter, those are their primary revenue sources. So if we look at a company like Google or Amazon or other major platforms, they're showing us that they have significantly other opportunities to generate revenue, particularly cloud computing, which really came through for Google in the most recent period. So Facebook is very, very dependent and its ability to expose a large number of users to all sorts of inputs, conduct this really large scale psychological experiment and sell that information to advertisers. That's what's really coming under pressure and Facebook doesn't have a lot of other options.

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: John, what you people invented with John Rogers on Chicago years ago in the Calvert Social Investment Fund, which at that time, folks, was absolutely revolutionary was, well, let's not buy tobacco, let's not buy this, let's not buy that. What has changed in social investment now? You were odd. Now, you're the norm. What is your day like in explaining the institutional money how to do social investment best?

STREUR: Well, that's -- thanks for the history. That's exactly right. I think what has really changed today is the amount of information that we have to work with to understand both what to buy as well as what you mentioned what not to buy. So today, our day is really all about understanding what is financially material in terms of environment performance, social impact, societal impact to companies.

KEENE: Put to rest the idea of rate of return. What is the tangible research you have, the tangible reality of rate of return or internal rate of return of social investment versus a blended SPX portfolio?

STREUR: Social investment can do anything non-social investment can do in terms of creating investment outcomes. There is really no reason to think about the return stream being different from social --

KEENE: Can you say the return stream is better? Can you say you're going to pick up 30 basis points with me?

STREUR: Well, I think you can say that. It depends on who is really applying the research though. So, as I said, we can do anything that you can do with non-social investing. We manufacture indexes at Calvert and they generally track the broad market. Sometimes we're slightly less risk, but that's the big measure. Can we create an inventory of securities that is capable to replicating the broad market returns. From there, sure, you can outperform especially if you add good active stock picking to that equation.

LACQUA: All right. John, thank you so much. John Streur there, President and Chief Executive Officer of Calvert Investment.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

JOHN STREUR, PRESIDENT AND CEO, CALVERT INVESTMENTS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB SURVEILLACNE

JULY 30, 2018

SPEAKERS: JOHN STREUR, PRESIDENT AND CEO, CALVERT INVESTMENTS

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Well, that investor is John Streur. He is the President and Chief Executive of Calvert Investments, and he joins us now from Washington D.C. John Streur, thank you so much for joining us. Where will this all end up? If you look at privacy, when you look at regulation, really, being spearheaded by, I guess, the European Union, but then also reaching across the channel and across, of course, the U.S., where does it end for a lot of these big tech companies?

JOHN STREUR, PRESIDENT AND CEO, CALVERT INVESTMENTS: Well, I think it ends in more regulation and higher costs for these companies, and that creates a significant amount of near term uncertainty in terms of how advertisers are going to respond to these changes.

LACQUA: Okay. Who will be the winners and who will be the losers? So, I mean, you say that you felt vindicated after you sell on Facebook. But Facebook could actually change more into something else.

STREUR: Look, I think it's (inaudible), I think Facebook's business model is fairly dependent upon their advertizing revenue. If we take a look at Facebook and Twitter, those are their primary revenue sources. So if we look at a company like Google or Amazon or other major platforms, they're showing us that they have significantly other opportunities to generate revenue, particularly cloud computing, which really came through for Google in the most recent period. So Facebook is very, very dependent and its ability to expose a large number of users to all sorts of inputs, conduct this really large scale psychological experiment and sell that information to advertisers. That's what's really coming under pressure and Facebook doesn't have a lot of other options.

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: John, what you people invented with John Rogers on Chicago years ago in the Calvert Social Investment Fund, which at that time, folks, was absolutely revolutionary was, well, let's not buy tobacco, let's not buy this, let's not buy that. What has changed in social investment now? You were odd. Now, you're the norm. What is your day like in explaining the institutional money how to do social investment best?

STREUR: Well, that's -- thanks for the history. That's exactly right. I think what has really changed today is the amount of information that we have to work with to understand both what to buy as well as what you mentioned what not to buy. So today, our day is really all about understanding what is financially material in terms of environment performance, social impact, societal impact to companies.

KEENE: Put to rest the idea of rate of return. What is the tangible research you have, the tangible reality of rate of return or internal rate of return of social investment versus a blended SPX portfolio?

STREUR: Social investment can do anything non-social investment can do in terms of creating investment outcomes. There is really no reason to think about the return stream being different from social --

KEENE: Can you say the return stream is better? Can you say you're going to pick up 30 basis points with me?

STREUR: Well, I think you can say that. It depends on who is really applying the research though. So, as I said, we can do anything that you can do with non-social investing. We manufacture indexes at Calvert and they generally track the broad market. Sometimes we're slightly less risk, but that's the big measure. Can we create an inventory of securities that is capable to replicating the broad market returns. From there, sure, you can outperform especially if you add good active stock picking to that equation.

LACQUA: All right. John, thank you so much. John Streur there, President and Chief Executive Officer of Calvert Investment.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

NEWS PROGRAM

JOHN STREUR, PRESIDENT AND CEO, CALVERT INVESTMENTS

LACQUA: Well, that investor is John Streur. He is the President and Chief Executive of Calvert Investments, and he joins us now from Washington D.C. John Streur, thank you so much for joining us. Where will this all end up? If you look at privacy, when you look at regulation, really, being spearheaded by, I guess, the European Union, but then also reaching across the channel and across, of course, the U.S., where does it end for a lot of these big tech companies?

STREUR: Well, I think it ends in more regulation and higher costs for these companies, and that creates a significant amount of near term uncertainty in terms of how advertisers are going to respond to these changes.

LACQUA: Okay. Who will be the winners and who will be the losers? So, I mean, you say that you felt vindicated after you sell on Facebook. But Facebook could actually change more into something else.

STREUR: Look, I think it's (inaudible), I think Facebook's business model is fairly dependent upon their advertizing revenue. If we take a look at Facebook and Twitter, those are their primary revenue sources. So if we look at a company like Google or Amazon or other major platforms, they're showing us that they have significantly other opportunities to generate revenue, particularly cloud computing, which really came through for Google in the most recent period. So Facebook is very, very dependent and its ability to expose a large number of users to all sorts of inputs, conduct this really large scale psychological experiment and sell that information to advertisers. That's what's really coming under pressure and Facebook doesn't have a lot of other options.

KEENE: John, what you people invented with John Rogers on Chicago years ago in the Calvert Social Investment Fund, which at that time, folks, was absolutely revolutionary was, well, let's not buy tobacco, let's not buy this, let's not buy that. What has changed in social investment now? You were odd. Now, you're the norm. What is your day like in explaining the institutional money how to do social investment best?

STREUR: Well, that's -- thanks for the history. That's exactly right. I think what has really changed today is the amount of information that we have to work with to understand both what to buy as well as what you mentioned what not to buy. So today, our day is really all about understanding what is financially material in terms of environment performance, social impact, societal impact to companies.

KEENE: Put to rest the idea of rate of return. What is the tangible research you have, the tangible reality of rate of return or internal rate of return of social investment versus a blended SPX portfolio?

STREUR: Social investment can do anything non-social investment can do in terms of creating investment outcomes. There is really no reason to think about the return stream being different from social --

KEENE: Can you say the return stream is better? Can you say you're going to pick up 30 basis points with me?

STREUR: Well, I think you can say that. It depends on who is really applying the research though. So, as I said, we can do anything that you can do with non-social investing. We manufacture indexes at Calvert and they generally track the broad market. Sometimes we're slightly less risk, but that's the big measure. Can we create an inventory of securities that is capable to replicating the broad market returns. From there, sure, you can outperform especially if you add good active stock picking to that equation.

LACQUA: All right. John, thank you so much. John Streur there, President and Chief Executive Officer of Calvert Investment.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WPX-F8P1-JD3N-51RF-00000-00Joining global push to rein in tech titans2019-08-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:18ZLexisNexisINQUIRERPg. 18Joining global push to rein in tech titansPaul Kelly, Editor-at-Large

Landmark ACCC report outlines best way forward

Australia's political class and public-interest agencies, like those in other democracies, are playing catch-up, given the big tech digital companies have pulled off the greatest regulatory escape in business history, achieving undreamed-of market power and threatening the democratic process.

The pledge given by Josh Frydenberg to confront the companies with a regulatory framework to combat a challenge "the world has never seen before" is one of the most important, daunting and far-reaching promises he has made as Treasurer.

This inaugurates a new politics: how to rein in the tech giants. The reaction to the 600-plus-page report from the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission is encouraging yet worrying in the extent to which the challenge posed by the digital platforms remains misunderstood.

Their operations, while loaded with opportunities for people and business, have the potential to undermine the market economy and the foundations of a viable democratic system. Every household with kids is at risk. The response must be set in this context. That task far transcends just another look at privacy and competition policy, though both these dimensions are critical.

ACCC chairman Rod Sims told Inquirer: "The business model of Facebook and Google rely on customers not actually understanding what data is being collected from them or how that data is being used. This problem needs to be comprehended and then it needs to be fixed." The Morrison government has accepted the challenge. There are three indispensable steps in the politics, without which the project will fail. First, political bipartisanship between the Coalition and Labor is essential - just recall how the absence of bipartisanship destroyed any viable energy policy for Australia.

Second, the entire project needs an informed public providing a strong electoral mandate for a new legislated regulatory regime. And third, Australia can only work in sync with the big jurisdictions of Europe and America and become an integral player in a global response. One of our tasks is to influence the global action.

Scott Morrison and Frydenberg are positioning along these lines. Separate, but related, is the OECD work on a digital tax to be completed by the end of next year. Frydenberg and the Prime Minister could be expected to move in unison with other nations and introduce an Australian digital tax to address the activities of the digital platforms. This means the tax may be legislated this term.

There has never been a challenge like this. The fascinating question is whether the challenge of the tech giants can bring a unity in politics, with agreement on the public interest more easily achieved than usual. The ACCC report is an outstanding start to the process. It must rank as one of the best diagnoses of the tech challenge provided by any government in the world. The hope is that the ACCC analysis will influence the approach and decisions in Washington.

The unknown factors are the risks in a serious challenge to these companies and whether a new regulatory regime can do the job. Nobody thinks unilateral action by Australia can turn the tide - yet we can serve as an awakening catalyst.

An optimistic Sims said: "I think our recommendations will have a huge impact because of their breadth. They deal with privacy, fairness and competition law, the deals these companies put to consumers, codes to enable media companies to bargain effectively with the digital platforms. Our recommendations are practical - we name the problem, then we specify the solution. And we do this across the board." The golden rule of reform still applies - throw sunlight on the way the public interest is betrayed. As a veteran of policy reform over 40 years, this is the method Sims uses in the report. Public awareness and education is at the heart of the ACCC strategy and it must be duplicated by the Morrison government.

The narrative history here resembles a fairytale. Remember the days of innocence when young kids in T-shirts and sneakers who didn't own a suit and looked totally benign offered a bright future that wise people guessed was too good to be true? The business model was unique - a free service driven by limitless demand with a technology as ubiquitous as anything ever invented.

That business model now looks different - it is predatory, based on monetising customer data largely in customer ignorance, abuse of market power and an astonishing indifference towards the social and cultural- consequences, many unintend-ed consequences, of the digital platforms.

The mental health problems of society are escalating towards an unprecedented crisis. US social psychologist Jonathan Haidt - one of the best analysts of contemporary society, who recently visit-ed Australia - warned that there was a "very good chance" US democracy would fail in the next 30 years and that digital platforms are central to this malaise. He said social media "shreds any network of social understandings or meanings".

There are two brands of critic-ism of the ACCC report: by economic liberals and libertarians that it is too interventionist and by tech gurus that it is a useless pop gun against the unstoppable march of technological innovation.

The first critique misreads the times and the dynamic at work. The lesson of the current age is writ large: the liberal market economy- is at risk from abuses by banks, energy companies and tech giants and effective regulation is the indispensable response. Any notion that these institutions will reform themselves is manifestly false. No rational politician would believe this. The market economy cannot survive without governments discharging their solemn task of strong regulation.

The second critique leads inexor-ably to demands for stronger action and falls prey to the "silver- bullet" mentality. US Democrat contender Elizabeth Warren waves a "big stick" and calls for the companies to be broken- up. This means a long legal delay of many years and puts too many eggs in the divestment basket-. There is no surety that break-ups will solve the problem.

In his penetrating article last week, commentator Alan Kohler analysed the options and concluded that licensing the companies is probably the "only thing" that makes a serious difference. Maybe - but what credibility does withdrawing a licence have, given no recent Australian government has done this for a bank or energy company?

"Some of the comments about our report are longing for a silver bullet," Sims said. "But in life there are rarely silver bullets. Our purpose- is not to kill Google or Facebook. We want to address these problems, not take the -companies out of existence." The ACCC report defines the strategic framework for tackling the tech giants. First, the method must be holistic - that means integ-rating the different legislative approaches of consumer, competition and privacy law. "A siloed -approach will fail," the report said. "People cannot understand the problem posed by these companies until they see its breadth," Sims said. The ACCC leans towards a whole-of-government strategy.

Second, the method must addres-s challenges now but also provide a permanent information stream to meet future new problems as they arise. "Our recommendations are designed to give the government and public the ongoing- information they need to stay ahead of this game," Sims said.

Third, the awareness of individual customers is the enduring reform- strategy, with the report saying: "The ACCC's view is that few consumers are fully informed of, fully understand, or effectively control, the scope of data collected and the bargain they are entering into with digital platforms when they sign up for, or use, their -services." This is an intolerable situation. It is idle to think such consumer -ignorance is not a fundamental part of the big-tech business model. The report said: "There is a substantial disconnect between how consumers think their data should be treated and how it is actually treated. Digital platforms collect vast troves of data on consumers from ever-expanding sources and have significant discretion over how this user data is used and disclosed- to other businesses and organisations, both now and in the future." Studies show that when people are told what happens to their data, 90 per cent report they are uncomfortable with the situation. The dictum that "you can only use my platform if you give me your data" must be dismantled.

Frydenberg was conspicuously strong in his response to the -report. He said: "The world has never seen before so much personally and commercially sensitive data collected, let alone aggregated and held by just two companies. Our legislative and regulatory framework did not and could not anticipate such a new paradigm. The government accepts the ACCC's overriding conclusion that there is a need for reform." Each month about 19.2 million Australians use Google search and 17.3 million access Facebook. The share price of both companies contain-s a hefty margin for projected future growth, estimated at 46-64 per cent of the existing share price for Google. Both companie-s generate most of their revenue from advertising, offering unique opportunities for advert-isers. The ACCC finds they have substantial market power in the supply of search services, search advertising and in dealings with established news businesses.

The high barriers to entry on these fronts underpin their market power. About 95 per cent of general searches in Australia are done through Google, which earns -almost 96 per cent of all search advert-ising revenue. Sims brands the attitude of the companies as akin to "trust us". He repudiates in the public interest the notion that the issues covered in the ACCC report- can be left to the companies.

The report recommends a specialist digital platforms branch be created within the ACCC to monitor and act against anti-competitiv-e conduct and consumer harm. It should be empowered by ministers to hold extended public inquiries, covering a period of at least five years, with power to compel information from companies.

The ACCC recommends action to address the vast imbalance in the bargaining relationship between- Google and Facebook on one hand and news media business on the other.

This is an asymmetrical relationship because news media businesses need Google and Facebook referrals more than each digital platform needs an individual media business's content. This issue leads directly to the attrition of journalism, with classified -advertising revenue falling from $2 billion in 2001 to $200 million in 2016 and a sharp decline in newspaper titles, the number of journalists and the breadth and depth of much reporting.

The effect of the ACCC recom-mendation is that Google and Facebook would be forced to share data and revenue more fairly from content generated by media businesses. This would involve codes of conduct governing relations betwee-n digital companies and media businesses that are policed by the Australian Communic-ations and Media Authority.

The aim is to correct the current- power imbalance with its adverse consequence for the public- interest. The intent is a more unified media regulatory framework. Further codes of conduct will govern the handling of complaints about disinformation and untrustworthy or fake news.

The justification for such actions- is undeniable. The digital platforms are changing the fundamental conditions under which people receive and manage inform-ation, penetrating to the functioning of the democratic -system.

The ACCC report said of the activities of the digital platforms: "This may have the effect of under-mining democratic processes" - a mild observation since the reality is that democratic processes- are already being undermined. The idea that governments have no role or responsibility to maintain the framework that sustains our democracy is untenable.

The ACCC puts a heavy emph-asis on global action, with a -summary of action taken in Britain, the EU and the US. It says co-ordination across borders is "critical" and the plan is for the new digital platforms branch within the ACCC to work closely with parallel teams in other countries.

"I think there is a big catch-up job to do," Sims said. "We don't doubt this. Why are we so far behind-? Well, these are relatively new companies. Their market power has grown very quickly. They came offering free services and it has taken people a while to begin to work out what is happening. And the companies have changed. These companies are not the same as they were just five years ago." This issue is not just about business- and technology. It goes to the way people live and interact on a daily basis. It is true that technol-ogy moves much faster than the ability of governments and regul-atory agencies to respond. It was inconceivable 15 years ago to imagine- the vast changes to be wrought by the digital companies. Their pluses were brilliantly obvious but their downsides have only slowly become more apparent.

Few doubt the magnitude of the task facing governments. Yet arguing that government should allow these companies to set their own rules in their own interests cannot be sustained in a democratic polity.The government will respond to the ACCC report by the end of the year. That will open a vast new field of public policy and political experimentation.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VV9-0XP1-DY08-327W-00000-00Joins BBC News - 00:00 AM GMT2019-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:18ZLexisNexisU.K. REGIONAL TVNewsJoins BBC News - 00:00 AM GMT

The latest national and international news from BBC News.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

You are watching Newsday on the BBC. I'm Sharanjit Leyl in Singapore, the headlines: Internet regulation - Britain follows Australia and announces a new crackdown on harmful content on the web. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing a service without providing the protection for users. In just a few hours, Israelis head to the polls with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu fighting for his political survival.

I'm Kasia Madera in London. Also in the programme. "Shameful and un-Australian", Australia's Prime Minister lashes out at animal rights campaigners who broke into abbatoirs and held up traffic. America's college entrance scandal: actress Felicity Huffman and 13 others plead guilty. Life from our studios in Singapore and at London, this is BBC World News. It is Newsday. -- live from our studios. Good morning. It's 8am in Singapore and one o'clock in London where the UK Government has become the latest to announce new regulations for the Internet. Firms that carry child abuse images or terrorist propaganda could be fined and even have their content blocked. There'll be a new watchdog and senior managers could be held criminally responsible for any breaches of the rules. It follows Australia's decision to ban harmful content - partly motivated by the live-streaming on Facebook of the Christchurch mosque shootings in which 50 people were shot dead. Critics argue the proposals threaten freedom of speech. Our Media Editor, Amol Rajan, reports. Over the past few years, the tech giants have come under sustained pressure to clean up their act. Terrorist propaganda such as the live broadcast of a recent attack in New Zealand have caused horror. So, too, have stories about child grooming online, and the appalling death of 14-year-old Molly Russell, who took her own life after seeing images of self-harm on Instagram - which is owned by Facebook - prompted an outcry. This long-delayed white paper is broad in scope and bold in its recommendations. For the first time, oversight of the internet will be entrusted to a regulator. A statutory duty of care to protect users will be enforced. And there is a potential for heavy fines to be administered. But many details remain unclear, which is why there's now a 12-week consultation. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing the service without providing the protection for users, that anyone who challenges them must be some kind of Luddite who just doesn't understand the modern world. Cabinet Ministers claim Britain will have the toughest Internet laws in the world. That is an exaggeration. The likes of Turkey, China, Dubai are much tougher. But Britain has sought inspiration from Germany, whose use of hate speech laws to curb online excess has been tentatively hailed as a success in the past year. Censorship is always bad, even in unfree society. It is the task and the responsibility of governments to maintain freedom of speech, but it is also the task of governments to stop using free speech if it violates other people. The new rules would apply to any company that allows people to share or discover user-generated content, or to interact with others. While Facebook welcomes the proposals in principle, they say any new rules must protect innovation and freedom of speech. Critics say applying the same rules to companies of such varying size will favour those few companies that can afford staff to oversee compliance, so entrenching the power of big tech. Amol Rajan, BBC News. We'll hear more on internet regulation from Australia shortly. First, let's take a look at some of the day's other news. British MPs have approved legislation forcing Prime Minister Theresa May to request to delay Brexit in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit this Friday. That's as talks between the UK Government and opposition Labour Party continue as they try to break the deadlock over Brexit. Mrs May will meet the French and German leaders on Tuesday to discuss Britain's options. Our Europe Editor Katya Adler is in Brussels. Michel Barnier, the EU's chief negotiator, says the EU remains united but they are not actually united at the moment. About whether to grant an extension, how long for, and under which conditions because the Prime Minister may say she wants a short extension until the 30th of June, but many EU leaders disagree because they cannot see the UK really getting everything together and ratifying a Brexit deal by that date.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VV9-0XP1-DY08-3259-00000-00Joins BBC News - 00:00 AM GMT2019-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:18ZLexisNexisU.K. REGIONAL TVNewsJoins BBC News - 00:00 AM GMT

The latest national and international news from BBC News.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

You are watching Newsday on the BBC. I'm Sharanjit Leyl in Singapore, the headlines: Internet regulation - Britain follows Australia and announces a new crackdown on harmful content on the web. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing a service without providing the protection for users. In just a few hours, Israelis head to the polls with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu fighting for his political survival.

I'm Kasia Madera in London. Also in the programme. "Shameful and un-Australian", Australia's Prime Minister lashes out at animal rights campaigners who broke into abbatoirs and held up traffic. America's college entrance scandal: actress Felicity Huffman and 13 others plead guilty. Life from our studios in Singapore and at London, this is BBC World News. It is Newsday. -- live from our studios. Good morning. It's 8am in Singapore and one o'clock in London where the UK Government has become the latest to announce new regulations for the Internet. Firms that carry child abuse images or terrorist propaganda could be fined and even have their content blocked. There'll be a new watchdog and senior managers could be held criminally responsible for any breaches of the rules. It follows Australia's decision to ban harmful content - partly motivated by the live-streaming on Facebook of the Christchurch mosque shootings in which 50 people were shot dead. Critics argue the proposals threaten freedom of speech. Our Media Editor, Amol Rajan, reports. Over the past few years, the tech giants have come under sustained pressure to clean up their act. Terrorist propaganda such as the live broadcast of a recent attack in New Zealand have caused horror. So, too, have stories about child grooming online, and the appalling death of 14-year-old Molly Russell, who took her own life after seeing images of self-harm on Instagram - which is owned by Facebook - prompted an outcry. This long-delayed white paper is broad in scope and bold in its recommendations. For the first time, oversight of the internet will be entrusted to a regulator. A statutory duty of care to protect users will be enforced. And there is a potential for heavy fines to be administered. But many details remain unclear, which is why there's now a 12-week consultation. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing the service without providing the protection for users, that anyone who challenges them must be some kind of Luddite who just doesn't understand the modern world. Cabinet Ministers claim Britain will have the toughest Internet laws in the world. That is an exaggeration. The likes of Turkey, China, Dubai are much tougher. But Britain has sought inspiration from Germany, whose use of hate speech laws to curb online excess has been tentatively hailed as a success in the past year. Censorship is always bad, even in unfree society. It is the task and the responsibility of governments to maintain freedom of speech, but it is also the task of governments to stop using free speech if it violates other people. The new rules would apply to any company that allows people to share or discover user-generated content, or to interact with others. While Facebook welcomes the proposals in principle, they say any new rules must protect innovation and freedom of speech. Critics say applying the same rules to companies of such varying size will favour those few companies that can afford staff to oversee compliance, so entrenching the power of big tech. Amol Rajan, BBC News. We'll hear more on internet regulation from Australia shortly. First, let's take a look at some of the day's other news. British MPs have approved legislation forcing Prime Minister Theresa May to request to delay Brexit in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit this Friday. That's as talks between the UK Government and opposition Labour Party continue as they try to break the deadlock over Brexit. Mrs May will meet the French and German leaders on Tuesday to discuss Britain's options. Our Europe Editor Katya Adler is in Brussels. Michel Barnier, the EU's chief negotiator, says the EU remains united but they are not actually united at the moment. About whether to grant an extension, how long for, and under which conditions because the Prime Minister may say she wants a short extension until the 30th of June, but many EU leaders disagree because they cannot see the UK really getting everything together and ratifying a Brexit deal by that date.

urn:contentItem:5VV9-0XP1-DY08-327T-00000-00Joins BBC News - 00:00 AM GMT2019-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:17ZLexisNexisU.K. REGIONAL TVNewsJoins BBC News - 00:00 AM GMT

The latest national and international news from BBC News.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

You are watching Newsday on the BBC. I'm Sharanjit Leyl in Singapore, the headlines: Internet regulation - Britain follows Australia and announces a new crackdown on harmful content on the web. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing a service without providing the protection for users. In just a few hours, Israelis head to the polls with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu fighting for his political survival.

I'm Kasia Madera in London. Also in the programme. "Shameful and un-Australian", Australia's Prime Minister lashes out at animal rights campaigners who broke into abbatoirs and held up traffic. America's college entrance scandal: actress Felicity Huffman and 13 others plead guilty. Life from our studios in Singapore and at London, this is BBC World News. It is Newsday. -- live from our studios. Good morning. It's 8am in Singapore and one o'clock in London where the UK Government has become the latest to announce new regulations for the Internet. Firms that carry child abuse images or terrorist propaganda could be fined and even have their content blocked. There'll be a new watchdog and senior managers could be held criminally responsible for any breaches of the rules. It follows Australia's decision to ban harmful content - partly motivated by the live-streaming on Facebook of the Christchurch mosque shootings in which 50 people were shot dead. Critics argue the proposals threaten freedom of speech. Our Media Editor, Amol Rajan, reports. Over the past few years, the tech giants have come under sustained pressure to clean up their act. Terrorist propaganda such as the live broadcast of a recent attack in New Zealand have caused horror. So, too, have stories about child grooming online, and the appalling death of 14-year-old Molly Russell, who took her own life after seeing images of self-harm on Instagram - which is owned by Facebook - prompted an outcry. This long-delayed white paper is broad in scope and bold in its recommendations. For the first time, oversight of the internet will be entrusted to a regulator. A statutory duty of care to protect users will be enforced. And there is a potential for heavy fines to be administered. But many details remain unclear, which is why there's now a 12-week consultation. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing the service without providing the protection for users, that anyone who challenges them must be some kind of Luddite who just doesn't understand the modern world. Cabinet Ministers claim Britain will have the toughest Internet laws in the world. That is an exaggeration. The likes of Turkey, China, Dubai are much tougher. But Britain has sought inspiration from Germany, whose use of hate speech laws to curb online excess has been tentatively hailed as a success in the past year. Censorship is always bad, even in unfree society. It is the task and the responsibility of governments to maintain freedom of speech, but it is also the task of governments to stop using free speech if it violates other people. The new rules would apply to any company that allows people to share or discover user-generated content, or to interact with others. While Facebook welcomes the proposals in principle, they say any new rules must protect innovation and freedom of speech. Critics say applying the same rules to companies of such varying size will favour those few companies that can afford staff to oversee compliance, so entrenching the power of big tech. Amol Rajan, BBC News. We'll hear more on internet regulation from Australia shortly. First, let's take a look at some of the day's other news. British MPs have approved legislation forcing Prime Minister Theresa May to request to delay Brexit in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit this Friday. That's as talks between the UK Government and opposition Labour Party continue as they try to break the deadlock over Brexit. Mrs May will meet the French and German leaders on Tuesday to discuss Britain's options. Our Europe Editor Katya Adler is in Brussels. Michel Barnier, the EU's chief negotiator, says the EU remains united but they are not actually united at the moment. About whether to grant an extension, how long for, and under which conditions because the Prime Minister may say she wants a short extension until the 30th of June, but many EU leaders disagree because they cannot see the UK really getting everything together and ratifying a Brexit deal by that date.

Cabinet Ministers claim Britain will have the toughest Internet laws in the world. That is an exaggeration. The likes of Turkey, China, Dubai are much tougher. But Britain has sought inspiration from Germany, whose use of hate speech laws to curb online excess has been tentatively hailed as a success in the past year. Censorship is always bad, even in unfree society. It is the task and the responsibility of governments to maintain freedom of speech, but it is also the task of governments to stop using free speech if it violates other people. The new rules would apply to any company that allows people to share or discover user-generated content, or to interact with others. While Facebook welcomes the proposals in principle, they say any new rules must protect innovation and freedom of speech. Critics say applying the same rules to companies of such varying size will favour those few companies that can afford staff to oversee compliance, so entrenching the power of big tech. Amol Rajan, BBC News. We'll hear more on internet regulation from Australia shortly. First, let's take a look at some of the day's other news. British MPs have approved legislation forcing Prime Minister Theresa May to request to delay Brexit in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit this Friday. That's as talks between the UK Government and opposition Labour Party continue as they try to break the deadlock over Brexit. Mrs May will meet the French and German leaders on Tuesday to discuss Britain's options. Our Europe Editor Katya Adler is in Brussels. Michel Barnier, the EU's chief negotiator, says the EU remains united but they are not actually united at the moment. About whether to grant an extension, how long for, and under which conditions because the Prime Minister may say she wants a short extension until the 30th of June, but many EU leaders disagree because they cannot see the UK really getting everything together and ratifying a Brexit deal by that date.

urn:contentItem:5VV9-0XP1-DY08-320B-00000-00Joins BBC News - 00:00 AM GMT2019-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:17ZLexisNexisU.K. REGIONAL TVNewsJoins BBC News - 00:00 AM GMT

The latest national and international news from BBC News.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

You are watching Newsday on the BBC. I'm Sharanjit Leyl in Singapore, the headlines: Internet regulation - Britain follows Australia and announces a new crackdown on harmful content on the web. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing a service without providing the protection for users. In just a few hours, Israelis head to the polls with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu fighting for his political survival.

I'm Kasia Madera in London. Also in the programme. "Shameful and un-Australian", Australia's Prime Minister lashes out at animal rights campaigners who broke into abbatoirs and held up traffic. America's college entrance scandal: actress Felicity Huffman and 13 others plead guilty. Life from our studios in Singapore and at London, this is BBC World News. It is Newsday. -- live from our studios. Good morning. It's 8am in Singapore and one o'clock in London where the UK Government has become the latest to announce new regulations for the Internet. Firms that carry child abuse images or terrorist propaganda could be fined and even have their content blocked. There'll be a new watchdog and senior managers could be held criminally responsible for any breaches of the rules. It follows Australia's decision to ban harmful content - partly motivated by the live-streaming on Facebook of the Christchurch mosque shootings in which 50 people were shot dead. Critics argue the proposals threaten freedom of speech. Our Media Editor, Amol Rajan, reports. Over the past few years, the tech giants have come under sustained pressure to clean up their act. Terrorist propaganda such as the live broadcast of a recent attack in New Zealand have caused horror. So, too, have stories about child grooming online, and the appalling death of 14-year-old Molly Russell, who took her own life after seeing images of self-harm on Instagram - which is owned by Facebook - prompted an outcry. This long-delayed white paper is broad in scope and bold in its recommendations. For the first time, oversight of the internet will be entrusted to a regulator. A statutory duty of care to protect users will be enforced. And there is a potential for heavy fines to be administered. But many details remain unclear, which is why there's now a 12-week consultation. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing the service without providing the protection for users, that anyone who challenges them must be some kind of Luddite who just doesn't understand the modern world. Cabinet Ministers claim Britain will have the toughest Internet laws in the world. That is an exaggeration. The likes of Turkey, China, Dubai are much tougher. But Britain has sought inspiration from Germany, whose use of hate speech laws to curb online excess has been tentatively hailed as a success in the past year. Censorship is always bad, even in unfree society. It is the task and the responsibility of governments to maintain freedom of speech, but it is also the task of governments to stop using free speech if it violates other people. The new rules would apply to any company that allows people to share or discover user-generated content, or to interact with others. While Facebook welcomes the proposals in principle, they say any new rules must protect innovation and freedom of speech. Critics say applying the same rules to companies of such varying size will favour those few companies that can afford staff to oversee compliance, so entrenching the power of big tech. Amol Rajan, BBC News. We'll hear more on internet regulation from Australia shortly. First, let's take a look at some of the day's other news. British MPs have approved legislation forcing Prime Minister Theresa May to request to delay Brexit in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit this Friday. That's as talks between the UK Government and opposition Labour Party continue as they try to break the deadlock over Brexit. Mrs May will meet the French and German leaders on Tuesday to discuss Britain's options. Our Europe Editor Katya Adler is in Brussels. Michel Barnier, the EU's chief negotiator, says the EU remains united but they are not actually united at the moment. About whether to grant an extension, how long for, and under which conditions because the Prime Minister may say she wants a short extension until the 30th of June, but many EU leaders disagree because they cannot see the UK really getting everything together and ratifying a Brexit deal by that date. Katya Adler with the latest on Brexit.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VV9-0XP1-DY08-328C-00000-00Joins BBC News - 00:00 AM GMT2019-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:18ZLexisNexisNORTHERN IRELAND, U.K.NewsJoins BBC News - 00:00 AM GMT

The latest national and international news from BBC News.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

You are watching Newsday on the BBC. I'm Sharanjit Leyl in Singapore, the headlines: Internet regulation - Britain follows Australia and announces a new crackdown on harmful content on the web. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing a service without providing the protection for users. In just a few hours, Israelis head to the polls with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu fighting for his political survival.

I'm Kasia Madera in London. Also in the programme. "Shameful and un-Australian", Australia's Prime Minister lashes out at animal rights campaigners who broke into abbatoirs and held up traffic. America's college entrance scandal: actress Felicity Huffman and 13 others plead guilty. Life from our studios in Singapore and at London, this is BBC World News. It is Newsday. -- live from our studios. Good morning. It's 8am in Singapore and one o'clock in London where the UK Government has become the latest to announce new regulations for the Internet. Firms that carry child abuse images or terrorist propaganda could be fined and even have their content blocked. There'll be a new watchdog and senior managers could be held criminally responsible for any breaches of the rules. It follows Australia's decision to ban harmful content - partly motivated by the live-streaming on Facebook of the Christchurch mosque shootings in which 50 people were shot dead. Critics argue the proposals threaten freedom of speech. Our Media Editor, Amol Rajan, reports. Over the past few years, the tech giants have come under sustained pressure to clean up their act. Terrorist propaganda such as the live broadcast of a recent attack in New Zealand have caused horror. So, too, have stories about child grooming online, and the appalling death of 14-year-old Molly Russell, who took her own life after seeing images of self-harm on Instagram - which is owned by Facebook - prompted an outcry. This long-delayed white paper is broad in scope and bold in its recommendations. For the first time, oversight of the internet will be entrusted to a regulator. A statutory duty of care to protect users will be enforced. And there is a potential for heavy fines to be administered. But many details remain unclear, which is why there's now a 12-week consultation. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing the service without providing the protection for users, that anyone who challenges them must be some kind of Luddite who just doesn't understand the modern world. Cabinet Ministers claim Britain will have the toughest Internet laws in the world. That is an exaggeration. The likes of Turkey, China, Dubai are much tougher. But Britain has sought inspiration from Germany, whose use of hate speech laws to curb online excess has been tentatively hailed as a success in the past year. Censorship is always bad, even in unfree society. It is the task and the responsibility of governments to maintain freedom of speech, but it is also the task of governments to stop using free speech if it violates other people. The new rules would apply to any company that allows people to share or discover user-generated content, or to interact with others. While Facebook welcomes the proposals in principle, they say any new rules must protect innovation and freedom of speech. Critics say applying the same rules to companies of such varying size will favour those few companies that can afford staff to oversee compliance, so entrenching the power of big tech. Amol Rajan, BBC News. We'll hear more on internet regulation from Australia shortly. First, let's take a look at some of the day's other news. British MPs have approved legislation forcing Prime Minister Theresa May to request to delay Brexit in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit this Friday. That's as talks between the UK Government and opposition Labour Party continue as they try to break the deadlock over Brexit. Mrs May will meet the French and German leaders on Tuesday to discuss Britain's options. Our Europe Editor Katya Adler is in Brussels. Michel Barnier, the EU's chief negotiator, says the EU remains united but they are not actually united at the moment. About whether to grant an extension, how long for, and under which conditions because the Prime Minister may say she wants a short extension until the 30th of June, but many EU leaders disagree because they cannot see the UK really getting everything together and ratifying a Brexit deal by that date.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VV9-0XP1-DY08-327N-00000-00Joins BBC News - 00:00 AM GMT2019-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:17ZLexisNexisU.K. NATIONALNewsJoins BBC News - 00:00 AM GMT

The latest national and international news from BBC News.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

You are watching Newsday on the BBC. I'm Sharanjit Leyl in Singapore, the headlines: Internet regulation - Britain follows Australia and announces a new crackdown on harmful content on the web. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing a service without providing the protection for users. In just a few hours, Israelis head to the polls with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu fighting for his political survival.

I'm Kasia Madera in London. Also in the programme. "Shameful and un-Australian", Australia's Prime Minister lashes out at animal rights campaigners who broke into abbatoirs and held up traffic. America's college entrance scandal: actress Felicity Huffman and 13 others plead guilty. Life from our studios in Singapore and at London, this is BBC World News. It is Newsday. -- live from our studios. Good morning. It's 8am in Singapore and one o'clock in London where the UK Government has become the latest to announce new regulations for the Internet. Firms that carry child abuse images or terrorist propaganda could be fined and even have their content blocked. There'll be a new watchdog and senior managers could be held criminally responsible for any breaches of the rules. It follows Australia's decision to ban harmful content - partly motivated by the live-streaming on Facebook of the Christchurch mosque shootings in which 50 people were shot dead. Critics argue the proposals threaten freedom of speech. Our Media Editor, Amol Rajan, reports. Over the past few years, the tech giants have come under sustained pressure to clean up their act. Terrorist propaganda such as the live broadcast of a recent attack in New Zealand have caused horror. So, too, have stories about child grooming online, and the appalling death of 14-year-old Molly Russell, who took her own life after seeing images of self-harm on Instagram - which is owned by Facebook - prompted an outcry. This long-delayed white paper is broad in scope and bold in its recommendations. For the first time, oversight of the internet will be entrusted to a regulator. A statutory duty of care to protect users will be enforced. And there is a potential for heavy fines to be administered. But many details remain unclear, which is why there's now a 12-week consultation. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing the service without providing the protection for users, that anyone who challenges them must be some kind of Luddite who just doesn't understand the modern world. Cabinet Ministers claim Britain will have the toughest Internet laws in the world. That is an exaggeration. The likes of Turkey, China, Dubai are much tougher. But Britain has sought inspiration from Germany, whose use of hate speech laws to curb online excess has been tentatively hailed as a success in the past year. Censorship is always bad, even in unfree society. It is the task and the responsibility of governments to maintain freedom of speech, but it is also the task of governments to stop using free speech if it violates other people. The new rules would apply to any company that allows people to share or discover user-generated content, or to interact with others. While Facebook welcomes the proposals in principle, they say any new rules must protect innovation and freedom of speech. Critics say applying the same rules to companies of such varying size will favour those few companies that can afford staff to oversee compliance, so entrenching the power of big tech. Amol Rajan, BBC News. We'll hear more on internet regulation from Australia shortly. First, let's take a look at some of the day's other news. British MPs have approved legislation forcing Prime Minister Theresa May to request to delay Brexit in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit this Friday. That's as talks between the UK Government and opposition Labour Party continue as they try to break the deadlock over Brexit. Mrs May will meet the French and German leaders on Tuesday to discuss Britain's options. Our Europe Editor Katya Adler is in Brussels. Michel Barnier, the EU's chief negotiator, says the EU remains united but they are not actually united at the moment. About whether to grant an extension, how long for, and under which conditions because the Prime Minister may say she wants a short extension until the 30th of June, but many EU leaders disagree because they cannot see the UK really getting everything together and ratifying a Brexit deal by that date.

A statutory duty of care to protect users will be enforced. And there is a potential for heavy fines to be administered. But many details remain unclear, which is why there's now a 12-week consultation. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing the service without providing the protection for users, that anyone who challenges them must be some kind of Luddite who just doesn't understand the modern world. Cabinet Ministers claim Britain will have the toughest Internet laws in the world. That is an exaggeration. The likes of Turkey, China, Dubai are much tougher. But Britain has sought inspiration from Germany, whose use of hate speech laws to curb online excess has been tentatively hailed as a success in the past year. Censorship is always bad, even in unfree society. It is the task and the responsibility of governments to maintain freedom of speech, but it is also the task of governments to stop using free speech if it violates other people. The new rules would apply to any company that allows people to share or discover user-generated content, or to interact with others. While Facebook welcomes the proposals in principle, they say any new rules must protect innovation and freedom of speech. Critics say applying the same rules to companies of such varying size will favour those few companies that can afford staff to oversee compliance, so entrenching the power of big tech. Amol Rajan, BBC News. We'll hear more on internet regulation from Australia shortly. First, let's take a look at some of the day's other news. British MPs have approved legislation forcing Prime Minister Theresa May to request to delay Brexit in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit this Friday. That's as talks between the UK Government and opposition Labour Party continue as they try to break the deadlock over Brexit. Mrs May will meet the French and German leaders on Tuesday to discuss Britain's options. Our Europe Editor Katya Adler is in Brussels. Michel Barnier, the EU's chief negotiator, says the EU remains united but they are not actually united at the moment. About whether to grant an extension, how long for, and under which conditions because the Prime Minister may say she wants a short extension until the 30th of June, but many EU leaders disagree because they cannot see the UK really getting everything together and ratifying a Brexit deal by that date. The latest national and international news from BBC News.

You are watching Newsday on the BBC. I'm Sharanjit Leyl in Singapore, the headlines: Internet regulation - Britain follows Australia and announces a new crackdown on harmful content on the web. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing a service without providing the protection for users. In just a few hours, Israelis head to the polls with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu fighting for his political survival.

I'm Kasia Madera in London. Also in the programme. "Shameful and un-Australian", Australia's Prime Minister lashes out at animal rights campaigners who broke into abbatoirs and held up traffic. America's college entrance scandal: actress Felicity Huffman and 13 others plead guilty. Life from our studios in Singapore and at London, this is BBC World News. It is Newsday. -- live from our studios. Good morning. It's 8am in Singapore and one o'clock in London where the UK Government has become the latest to announce new regulations for the Internet. Firms that carry child abuse images or terrorist propaganda could be fined and even have their content blocked. There'll be a new watchdog and senior managers could be held criminally responsible for any breaches of the rules. It follows Australia's decision to ban harmful content - partly motivated by the live-streaming on Facebook of the Christchurch mosque shootings in which 50 people were shot dead. Critics argue the proposals threaten freedom of speech. Our Media Editor, Amol Rajan, reports. Over the past few years, the tech giants have come under sustained pressure to clean up their act. Terrorist propaganda such as the live broadcast of a recent attack in New Zealand have caused horror. So, too, have stories about child grooming online, and the appalling death of 14-year-old Molly Russell, who took her own life after seeing images of self-harm on Instagram - which is owned by Facebook - prompted an outcry. This long-delayed white paper is broad in scope and bold in its recommendations. For the first time, oversight of the internet will be entrusted to a regulator. A statutory duty of care to protect users will be enforced. And there is a potential for heavy fines to be administered. But many details remain unclear, which is why there's now a 12-week consultation. Too many social media firms still seem to think that they can get away with providing the service without providing the protection for users, that anyone who challenges them must be some kind of Luddite who just doesn't understand the modern world. Cabinet Ministers claim Britain will have the toughest Internet laws in the world. That is an exaggeration. The likes of Turkey, China, Dubai are much tougher. But Britain has sought inspiration from Germany, whose use of hate speech laws to curb online excess has been tentatively hailed as a success in the past year. Censorship is always bad, even in unfree society. It is the task and the responsibility of governments to maintain freedom of speech, but it is also the task of governments to stop using free speech if it violates other people. The new rules would apply to any company that allows people to share or discover user-generated content, or to interact with others. While Facebook welcomes the proposals in principle, they say any new rules must protect innovation and freedom of speech. Critics say applying the same rules to companies of such varying size will favour those few companies that can afford staff to oversee compliance, so entrenching the power of big tech. Amol Rajan, BBC News. We'll hear more on internet regulation from Australia shortly. First, let's take a look at some of the day's other news. British MPs have approved legislation forcing Prime Minister Theresa May to request to delay Brexit in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit this Friday. That's as talks between the UK Government and opposition Labour Party continue as they try to break the deadlock over Brexit. Mrs May will meet the French and German leaders on Tuesday to discuss Britain's options. Our Europe Editor Katya Adler is in Brussels. Michel Barnier, the EU's chief negotiator, says the EU remains united but they are not actually united at the moment. About whether to grant an extension, how long for, and under which conditions because the Prime Minister may say she wants a short extension until the 30th of June, but many EU leaders disagree because they cannot see the UK really getting everything together and ratifying a Brexit deal by that date.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VV9-0XP1-DY08-3266-00000-00Joins BBC News - 00:05 AM GMT2019-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:17ZLexisNexisU.K. REGIONAL TVNewsJoins BBC News - 00:05 AM GMT

The latest national and international news from BBC News.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

Katya Adler with the latest on Brexit. Also making news today... US secretary of State Mike Pompeo has barred 16 Saudis from entering the United States for the State Department described as their involvement in the killing of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The State Department previously revoked the visas of nearly two dozen Saudi officials and froze the assets of 17 others. US President Donald Trump is removing the director of the Secret Service, the agency that provides protection for him and other top officials.

The dismissal of Randolph "Tex" Alles comes just a day after his boss, the Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen, left her post. Mr Alles has denied suggestions he was fired, saying he was told weeks ago to expect a 'transition in leadership'. A Hong Kong court is expected to deliver its verdict in the controversial trial of three democracy campaigners over their participation in the so-called Umbrella Movement in 2014. They're among nine activists facing colonial-era public nuisance charges in relation to the protests, which called for free elections. The charges carry jail terms of up to seven years. Nissan shareholders have voted to remove the company's former boss Carlos Ghosn from its board. The decision to sever ties with Mr Ghosn was made at a shareholders meeting. The former chairman of Nissan was re-arrested in Tokyo last week while out on bail pending trial over claims of financial misconduct. He was first detained in November. The UK is the latest country to question the use of Huawei technology in its 5G network. The United States has been warning its allies that Huawei's technology could make them vulnerable to Chinese state espionage or cyber attacks - something Huawei denies. It is known as the toughest foot race on earth, the seven-day Marathon des Sables is taking place in the Sahara Desert in southern Morocco. It covers a distance of 251km, equivalent to six regular marathons. Almost 1,000 competitors are participating in this year's event, racing across inhospitable terrain in the blazing heat. The so-called ultramarathon has been held annually since 1986. As we've heard, the era of self-regulation for giant tech companies such as Facebook is coming to an end. Britain has followed Australia in announcing enforcement powers including the ability to fine companies that break the rules. But how difficult is it to police the internet? I put that question to the head of the International Cyber Policy Centre - Fergus Hanson - who joined me from Canberra a short time ago. Well, it is hugely difficult. If you think about it, just targeting Facebook and looking at these big tech companies, but really there is a whole world of much smaller companies that are almost impossible to reach. If you take the Christchurch terrorist video, that was actually disseminated largely through a group called 8Chan, which most people probably never heard of but there is a whole bunch of these little websites that are just really very difficult to reach and hard to regulate. How big an appetite is there around the world for some kind of accountability for what has happened online? We have been talking about those awful Christchurch shootings the fact they were live streamed... Shouldn't something like that not be allowed to happen again? Yes, I think you feel and hear that Christchurch shooting video really has stirred people up. It is was a horrendous attack and people I think really want to see more action taken against companies that are facilitating the sharing of these videos. The big question though is how do you do that. Are we going to start treating these companies as broadcasters and apply the same rules or will we start saying everybody is a publisher now and individuals have to start taking a bit more responsibility? Personally, I think we need to do a little bit of a mix of both. We cannot just let individuals off scott free and have no responsibility for what they are sharing online. There's been a lot of concern as well, particularly where you are in Australia, that these new rules were rushed through, a lot of concerns about censorship. That is right. In Australia, a new law has passed Parliament that essentially empowers what we call our Re-safety Commission, who are responsible for making sure that Australians feel safe online. And they have given the power to issue notices to companies saying they are hosting abhorent content which is essentially a signal that they have to remove it instantly. Unfortunately, the laws do not actually spell out how quickly they have to remove it, they were raced through Parliament, drafted over a weekend,

urn:contentItem:5VV9-0XP1-DY08-324T-00000-00Joins BBC News - 00:05 AM GMT2019-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:04:18ZLexisNexisU.K. REGIONAL TVNewsJoins BBC News - 00:05 AM GMT

The latest national and international news from BBC News.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

Katya Adler with the latest on Brexit. Also making news today... US secretary of State Mike Pompeo has barred 16 Saudis from entering the United States for the State Department described as their involvement in the killing of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The State Department previously revoked the visas of nearly two dozen Saudi officials and froze the assets of 17 others. US President Donald Trump is removing the director of the Secret Service, the agency that provides protection for him and other top officials.

The dismissal of Randolph "Tex" Alles comes just a day after his boss, the Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen, left her post. Mr Alles has denied suggestions he was fired, saying he was told weeks ago to expect a 'transition in leadership'. A Hong Kong court is expected to deliver its verdict in the controversial trial of three democracy campaigners over their participation in the so-called Umbrella Movement in 2014. They're among nine activists facing colonial-era public nuisance charges in relation to the protests, which called for free elections. The charges carry jail terms of up to seven years. Nissan shareholders have voted to remove the company's former boss Carlos Ghosn from its board. The decision to sever ties with Mr Ghosn was made at a shareholders meeting. The former chairman of Nissan was re-arrested in Tokyo last week while out on bail pending trial over claims of financial misconduct. He was first detained in November. The UK is the latest country to question the use of Huawei technology in its 5G network. The United States has been warning its allies that Huawei's technology could make them vulnerable to Chinese state espionage or cyber attacks - something Huawei denies. It is known as the toughest foot race on earth, the seven-day Marathon des Sables is taking place in the Sahara Desert in southern Morocco. It covers a distance of 251km, equivalent to six regular marathons. Almost 1,000 competitors are participating in this year's event, racing across inhospitable terrain in the blazing heat. The so-called ultramarathon has been held annually since 1986. As we've heard, the era of self-regulation for giant tech companies such as Facebook is coming to an end. Britain has followed Australia in announcing enforcement powers including the ability to fine companies that break the rules. But how difficult is it to police the internet? I put that question to the head of the International Cyber Policy Centre - Fergus Hanson - who joined me from Canberra a short time ago. Well, it is hugely difficult. If you think about it, just targeting Facebook and looking at these big tech companies, but really there is a whole world of much smaller companies that are almost impossible to reach. If you take the Christchurch terrorist video, that was actually disseminated largely through a group called 8Chan, which most people probably never heard of but there is a whole bunch of these little websites that are just really very difficult to reach and hard to regulate. How big an appetite is there around the world for some kind of accountability for what has happened online? We have been talking about those awful Christchurch shootings the fact they were live streamed... Shouldn't something like that not be allowed to happen again? Yes, I think you feel and hear that Christchurch shooting video really has stirred people up. It is was a horrendous attack and people I think really want to see more action taken against companies that are facilitating the sharing of these videos. The big question though is how do you do that. Are we going to start treating these companies as broadcasters and apply the same rules or will we start saying everybody is a publisher now and individuals have to start taking a bit more responsibility? Personally, I think we need to do a little bit of a mix of both. We cannot just let individuals off scott free and have no responsibility for what they are sharing online. There's been a lot of concern as well, particularly where you are in Australia, that these new rules were rushed through, a lot of concerns about censorship. That is right. In Australia, a new law has passed Parliament that essentially empowers what we call our Re-safety Commission, who are responsible for making sure that Australians feel safe online. And they have given the power to issue notices to companies saying they are hosting abhorent content which is essentially a signal that they have to remove it instantly. Unfortunately, the laws do not actually spell out how quickly they have to remove it, they were raced through Parliament, drafted over a weekend,
